commit_message:
Allow the usage of a passed in sqlalchemy engine

In certain use-cases a user of taskflow will likely
have a pre-existing engine that they want to use with
out SQLAlchemyBackend. To allow them to provide such
an engine via the backends constructor for use-cases
where this makes sense.

At the same time move the validation function the
connection class so that it can be called by users
to verify their connection is valid.

Change-Id: I8150194570a84e19712d7d4ca66b79b7161a76e7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/25/70225/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from sqlalchemy import engine as sa_eng def __init__(self, conf, engine=None): if engine: if not isinstance(engine, sa_eng.Engine): raise TypeError("Provided engine must be an instance of" " a sqlalchemy engine and not %s" % type(engine)) self._engine = engine self._owns_engine = False else: self._engine = None self._owns_engine = True if self._session_maker: self._session_maker = None if self._engine and self._owns_engine: self._engine = None
deleted_lines: def __init__(self, conf): self._engine = None if self._session_maker is not None: if self._engine is not None: self._engine = None self._session_maker = None

commit_message:
Remove versionId, versionInfo, versionList from examples

I recall these attributes being discussed at one point
(pre-incubation?), but have never been supported by OpenStack and don't
appear to be defined in any v2.0 WADL/XSD specification.

Change-Id: Ia5b691972c70456e3d62750173e2bfc6e9aec55a
Closes-Bug: 1273831
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/71/69971/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
The misterious sleep which removes the sins of nova-cpu

I am justing verifying that a sleep would really prevent the hang
observed in the compute service when injection is disabled.
Then, if that is confirmed, I would love to understand where this
weird racey behaviour would be coming from.

Change-Id: I0719e2d2e4cf3828a90ba28695e1633c51926708
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/02/71002/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: else: # For some mysterious reason if you remove this line the compute # service will hang if not doing injection. time.sleep(0.5)

commit_message:
Who wants namespace processes to live forever?

I will spare you the pain of another song lyrics.

This is an attempt at verifying whether this 'last resort'
approach might be adopted while we sort our issues with the
kernel.

Change-Id: I8f16336cfd074ece243c22216f039aa9ed6c1ad1

commit_message:
Rename nvp_cluster for VMware NSX plugin

Rename the module into nsx_cluster and the class into NSXCluster,
and update references accordingly.

Also, rename utility method create_nvp_cluster to create_nsx_cluster
and move it into nsx_utils.

Partial-implements blueprint: nicira-plugin-renaming

Change-Id: I1a943cc64730ea67f464c3804370dad46411f8a2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/70/68370/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Cleanup docstrings

Some docstrings were not valid RST, which led to incorrect display
and warnings and errors when building the docs.

Change-Id: I66d823a2a5a2a05d51ba1a37a2c22ded2c09f748
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/09/70009/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - domain_admin_user has role 'admin' on domainA, - project_admin_user has role 'admin' on the project, - just_a_user has a non-admin role on both domainA and the project.
deleted_lines: - domain_admin_user has role 'admin' on domainA, - project_admin_user has role 'admin' on the project, - just_a_user has a non-admin role on both domainA and the project.

commit_message:
Change 'oauth_extension' to 'oauth1_extension'

The documentation uses 'oauth1_extension' but the configuration files
an tests use 'oauth_extension'. This change sets all of them to
oauth1_extension.

Closes-Bug: #1275693
Change-Id: I279f08e262d6f1ae8afea58fd46576e3eabf3875
DocImpact: Extension name has been changed in keystone-paste.ini,
therefore the pipeline may need to be adjusted as well
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/91/70691/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 2. Add the ``oauth_extension`` filter to the ``api_v3`` pipeline in ``keystone-paste.ini``. For example:: pipeline = access_log sizelimit url_normalize token_auth admin_token_auth xml_body json_body ec2_extension s3_extension oauth_extension service_v3
deleted_lines: 2. Add the ``oauth1_extension`` filter to the ``api_v3`` pipeline in ``keystone-paste.ini``. For example:: pipeline = access_log sizelimit url_normalize token_auth admin_token_auth xml_body json_body ec2_extension s3_extension oauth1_extension service_v3

subject: Process port_update notifications in the main agent loop
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-12-13 11:11:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/1468eb92da64b929b226544412d4df62a3e70002', 'message': "Process port_update notifications in the main agent loop

Instead of processing a port update notification directly in
the RPC call, the actual processing is moved into the main
rpc loop, whereas the RPC call just adds the updated port
identifier to a set of updated ports.
In this way, a port_update notification won't compete with the
main rpc loop, causing long delays into its completion under
heavy load. Also, repeated port_update notifications received
within a single iteration of the main agent loop will be
coalesced and processed only once.

This will also avoid the risk of processing notifications out
of order thus ending up with an actual configuration which
differs from the desired one.

This patch also stops performing treat_vif_port for updated
ports. Indeed this would be needed only if the host for a port is
updated, but in that case the main loop will identify this port
as 'added' thus processing it anyway. L2 wiring for updated
ports won't be necessary until updates to provider network
attributes are not supported.

The update_ports method has been renamed to scan_ports as the latter
name appear to be more in line with what the method actually does.

Partial-Bug: #1253993
Change-Id: I219c6bdf63b0b5e945b655677f9e28fa591f03cd
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2013-12-13 12:42:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/c141b9b12f59536ff19423032a7182446d71a84a', 'message': "Process port_update notifications in the main agent loop

"}, {'number': 11, 'created': '2013-12-18 13:55:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/96d0f7ae297906609edf7ca29da4f677bcfc629f', 'message': "Process port_update notifications in the main agent loop

Instead of processing a port update notification directly in
the RPC call, the actual processing is moved into the main
rpc loop, whereas the RPC call just adds the updated port
identifier to a set of updated ports.
In this way, a port_update notification won't compete with the
main rpc loop, causing long delays into its completion under
heavy load. Also, repeated port_update notifications received
within a single iteration of the main agent loop will be
coalesced and processed only once.
This will also avoid the risk of processing notifications out
of order thus ending up with an actual configuration which
differs from the desired one.

This patch still performs L2 wiring for updated ports even if
it is necessary only when the administrative state of a port
changes.

The update_ports method has been renamed to scan_ports as the latter
name appears to be more in line with what the method actually does.

commit_message:
Process port_update notifications in the main agent loop

Instead of processing a port update notification directly in
the RPC call, the actual processing is moved into the main
rpc loop, whereas the RPC call just adds the updated port
identifier to a set of updated ports.
In this way, a port_update notification won't compete with the
main rpc loop, causing long delays into its completion under
heavy load. Also, repeated port_update notifications received
within a single iteration of the main agent loop will be
coalesced and processed only once.
This will also avoid the risk of processing notifications out
of order thus ending up with an actual configuration which
differs from the desired one.

This patch still performs L2 wiring for updated ports even if
it is necessary only when the administrative state of a port
changes.

The update_ports method has been renamed to scan_ports as the latter
name appears to be more in line with what the method actually does.

Partial-Bug: #1253993
Partially implements blueprint: neutron-tempest-parallel
Change-Id: I219c6bdf63b0b5e945b655677f9e28fa591f03cd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/64/61964/22 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: 'update_ports'), ) as (log_exception, update_ports, process_network_ports): update_ports.side_effect = [reply2, reply3] update_ports.assert_has_calls([ mock.call(set()), mock.call(set(['tap0']))

commit_message:
Minimize the cost of checking for api worker exit

A recent change to oslo allows the configuration of the interval
that ProcessLauncher waits between checks of child exit.  The
default interval of 0.01s resulted in the neutron service consuming
unnecessary cpu cycles checking whether api workers had exited (5%
cpu on idle in a VM).  This patch extends the interval to 1s to
minimize the cost of the checks.

Change-Id: I0407ccb2db65cd3839586faff15e70dbc35f005e
Closes-bug: #1095346
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/19/67919/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Minimize the cost of checking for child exit by extending the # wait interval past the default of 0.1s. self._launcher = ProcessLauncher(wait_interval=1.0)

commit_message:
Cleanup extension development docs

There were instances where the title was too long.
Also, there was an issue with a code example, however I removed it,
as it was duplicated a few lines above.
The duplicated function was updated with the correct parameters.

Change-Id: Ied955e8a0a9991177a824b2995ed556d90af907a

commit_message:
Run zookeeper tests if localhost has a compat. zookeeper server

If a local zookeeper server is running then using that
zookeeper server we are able to run the zookeeper tests,
so instead of always turning these tests off; only turn
them off if no zookeeper server is found.

Change-Id: I27bbc67b4f2d03a4469882fdc3b8015324ad7e3b

added_lines: import contextlib from kazoo import exceptions as k_excfrom taskflow.openstack.common import uuidutilsfrom taskflow.utils import kazoo_utils TEST_CONFIG = { 'timeout': 1.0, 'hosts': "localhost:2181", } TEST_PATH = '/taskflow/persistence-test/%s' def _zookeeper_exists(): client = kazoo_utils.make_client(TEST_CONFIG) try: client.start() client.sync("/") return True except client.handler.timeout_exception: return False except (k_exc.KazooException, k_exc.ZookeeperError): return False finally: client.stop() client.close() @testtools.skipIf(not _zookeeper_exists(), 'zookeeper is not available') return self.backend.get_connection() def _clear_all(self): with contextlib.closing(self._get_connection()) as conn: conn.clear_all() conf = TEST_CONFIG.copy() conf['path'] = TEST_PATH % (uuidutils.generate_uuid()) self.backend = impl_zookeeper.ZkBackend(conf) self.addCleanup(self.backend.close) with contextlib.closing(self._get_connection()) as conn: conn.upgrade() self.addCleanup(self._clear_all)
deleted_lines: @testtools.skipIf(True, 'ZooKeeper is not available in Jenkins') return self._backend.get_connection() conf = { 'hosts': "192.168.0.1:2181,192.168.0.2:2181,192.168.0.3:2181", 'path': "/taskflow", } self._backend = impl_zookeeper.ZkBackend(conf) conn = self._get_connection() conn.upgrade() def tearDown(self): super(ZkPersistenceTest, self).tearDown() conn = self._get_connection() conn.clear_all()

commit_message:
run disable commands in namespace

This alters the external_process manager and the dnsmasq manager to execute kill
commands inside of the correct namespace.

Change-Id: I077099642dfe8dbcc2f5de083168a2f743f5a6af
Related-Bug: 1273386
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/53/69653/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: with mock.patch.object(ep, 'ip_lib') as ip_lib: ip_lib.assert_has_calls([ mock.call.IPWrapper('sudo', 'ns'), mock.call.IPWrapper().netns.execute(['kill', '-9', 4])] )
deleted_lines: with mock.patch.object(ep, 'utils') as utils: utils.assert_has_calls( mock.call.execute(['kill', '-9', 4], 'sudo'))

subject: Sshutils refactoring
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-21 10:41:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/rally/commit/0c9520bb9fc564efa79e53dd89464d9c42d6923c', 'message': "Sshutils refactoring

Paramiko sftp client is not eventlet friendly. Also it doesn't work
with some servers, so upload/download methods has been removed.
Downloading or uploading can be done in other way (see examples).

Added ability to pass process stdin, which makes possible to
do on remote host anything at all.

Much more clean and usable API.

Change-Id: If357a2878c2c60646a975c386a0fe2f1616aec95

commit_message:
Sshutils refactoring

Paramiko sftp client is not eventlet friendly. Also it doesn't work
with some servers, so upload/download methods has been removed.
Downloading or uploading can be done in other way (see examples).

Added ability to pass process stdin, which makes possible to
do on remote host anything at all.

Much more clean and usable API.

Change-Id: If357a2878c2c60646a975c386a0fe2f1616aec95
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/63/68063/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import StringIO server.ssh.run('/bin/sh -e', stdin=open(script_path, 'rb')) server.ssh.run('git clone %s' % devstack_repo) localrc = StringIO.StringIO() for k, v in self.localrc.iteritems(): localrc.write('%s=%s\n' % (k, v)) localrc.seek(0) server.ssh.run("cat > ~/devstack/localrc", stdin=localrc) server.ssh.run('~/devstack/stack.sh')
deleted_lines: import tempfile server.ssh.execute_script(script_path) server.ssh.execute('git', 'clone', devstack_repo) fd, config_path = tempfile.mkstemp() config_file = open(config_path, "w") for k, v in self.localrc.iteritems(): config_file.write('%s=%s\n' % (k, v)) config_file.close() os.close(fd) server.ssh.upload(config_path, "~/devstack/localrc") os.unlink(config_path) server.ssh.execute('~/devstack/stack.sh')

commit_message:
Ensure mapping rule has only local and remote properties

As per the API spec, a mapping rule reference should only have a
local and remote properties.
This change ensures that the schema used to validate mappings
fulfills that requirement.

bp mapping-distributed-admin

Change-Id: I00468c56d9b6689789b2123c3797c56cc73517d1

subject: Add a helper function to find the config section by name
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/50/69250/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_config_by_name(config, name): """A helper function to find a dict whose name is 'name' in config json.""" if isinstance(config, dict): if config.get("name", None) == name: return config for k, v in config.iteritems(): ret = get_config_by_name(v, name) if ret is not None: return ret return None

commit_message:
Sync OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_DEFAULT_ROLE with keystone

For now, keystone default role is _member_, while horizon set
OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_DEFAULT_ROLE to Member. It will really be user
friendly to modify horizon default value to _member_ to sync with
keystone's default setting.

Conflicts:

    doc/source/topics/settings.rst

Change-Id: I55d15e6cfb74e52e933c5a44efd6c27930415738
Closes-Bug: #1264228
(cherry picked from commit 0aacc44f324c3db049f912da1f84d93c1142cb37)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/60/68060/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_DEFAULT_ROLE = "_member_"

commit_message:
find server boot time using datetime

cirros image doesn't recognize human readable date format. It complain
following error when this command is executed by a test case.
$ date -d "`cut -f1 -d. /proc/uptime` seconds ago" "+%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S"
date: invalid date '2336 seconds ago'

Get the boot time from /proc/uptime and calculate boot time using datetime.

Closes-Bug: 1244823
Change-Id: If5c295ec06921aae4c6a7eb0edba39ff9e3946bf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/37/65337/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from datetime import datetime, timedelta cmd = 'cut -f1 -d. /proc/uptime' # NOTE(bhuvan): Originally the uptime since in YYYY-mm-dd HH:MM:SS # format was returned from date command. The cirros image used here # don't support that format. Using python superiority to deal with it. # Filed https://bugs.launchpad.net/tempest/+bug/1244823 to fix it. boot_secs = self.ssh_client.exec_command(cmd) try: boot_secs = int(boot_secs) except ValueError, err: # NOTE(bhuvan): The command return empty string, when it is executed # immediately after the VM is up. If that's the case, re-try. boot_secs = self.ssh_client.exec_command(cmd) boot_time = datetime.now() - timedelta(seconds=int(boot_secs)) boot_time_string = boot_time.strftime(utils.LAST_REBOOT_TIME_FORMAT)
deleted_lines: cmd = 'date -d "`cut -f1 -d. /proc/uptime` seconds ago" \ "+%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S"' boot_time_string = self.ssh_client.exec_command(cmd) boot_time_string = boot_time_string.replace('\n', '')

commit_message:
Don't use metaclasses for thread-safe storage

Provide a wrapper that works as locking decorator instead of metaclass.
This solution should be better, because:
- it does not use metaclasses, so it's simpler;
- it locks the lock only on interface boundaries, which allows to use
  non-recursive locks and avoids some overhead;
- it has unit-tests.

Closes-bug: #1273146
Change-Id: I69d566345847a79cbda3463f3545be5357cd1762

commit_message:
Disallow single IP subnets in neutron

Currently, NeutronDbPluginV2._validate_subnet_cidr() only checks for
overlapping subnets.  It does no checking for a CIDR prefix which
would allow only one IP in the subnet.  Horizon prevents this in the
UI, but neutron does not so CLI can still push this invalid subnet
through.  This fix is to close this gap and disallow subnets with
only one IP.

Change-Id: Ic2c871749c2fa3c8d2bacecf1062bde0eca5bd6c
Closes-Bug: #1271311
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/42/68742/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Verifies two things: 1) The subnet has more than one IP address in it. ie, the prefix size is less than /32 2) The specified CIDR does not overlap with the ones defined for the other subnets specified for this network, or with any other CIDR if overlapping IPs are disabled. # Do not allow single IP networks net_range = netaddr.IPNetwork(new_subnet_cidr) if net_range.first == net_range.last: err_msg = (_("Requested subnet with cidr %(cidr)s for network " "%(network_name)s only contains a single valid IP. " "Please specify a larger subnet range") % {'cidr': new_subnet_cidr, 'network_name': network.name}) LOG.error(_("Validation for cidr %s failed - subnet only " "contains one valid IP address.") % new_subnet_cidr) raise q_exc.InvalidInput(error_message=err_msg)
deleted_lines: Verifies the specified CIDR does not overlap with the ones defined for the other subnets specified for this network, or with any other CIDR if overlapping IPs are disabled.

commit_message:
RPC service for software config/deployment

These RPC service methods are wrappers over the DB API.

Implements: blueprint hot-software-config-rest
Change-Id: I2c2e53f633cca30533b9190ebccc0d6eddcfb21f

added_lines: @request_context def show_software_config(self, cnxt, config_id): try: sc = db_api.software_config_get(cnxt, config_id) except Exception as ex: logger.warn('show_software_config db error %s' % str(ex)) return return api.format_software_config(sc) @request_context def create_software_config(self, cnxt, name, config, inputs={}, outputs={}): try: sc = db_api.software_config_create(cnxt, { 'name': name, 'config': config, 'inputs': inputs, 'outputs': outputs, 'tenant': cnxt.tenant_id }) except Exception as ex: logger.warn('create_software_config db error %s' % str(ex)) return return api.format_software_config(sc) @request_context def delete_software_config(self, cnxt, config_id): try: db_api.software_config_delete(cnxt, config_id) except Exception as ex: logger.warn('delete_software_config db error %s' % str(ex)) @request_context def list_software_deployments(self, cnxt, server_id=None): try: all_sd = db_api.software_deployment_get_all(cnxt, server_id) except Exception as ex: logger.warn('list_software_deployments db error %s' % str(ex)) return result = [api.format_software_deployment(sd) for sd in all_sd] return result @request_context def show_software_deployment(self, cnxt, deployment_id): try: sd = db_api.software_deployment_get(cnxt, deployment_id) except Exception as ex: logger.warn('show_software_deployment db error %s' % str(ex)) return return api.format_software_deployment(sd) @request_context def create_software_deployment(self, cnxt, server_id, config_id=None, input_values={}, signal_id=None): try: sd = db_api.software_deployment_create(cnxt, { 'config_id': config_id, 'server_id': server_id, 'input_values': input_values, 'signal_id': signal_id, 'tenant': cnxt.tenant_id, 'action': 'INIT', 'status': 'COMPLETE', }) except Exception as ex: logger.warn('create_software_deployment db error %s' % str(ex)) return return api.format_software_deployment(sd) @request_context def update_software_deployment(self, cnxt, deployment_id, config_id=None, input_values={}, output_values={}, action=None, status=None, status_reason=None): try: sd = db_api.software_deployment_update(cnxt, deployment_id, { 'config_id': config_id, 'input_values': input_values, 'output_values': output_values, 'action': action, 'status': status, 'status_reason': status_reason, }) except Exception as ex: logger.warn('update_software_deployment db error %s' % str(ex)) return return api.format_software_deployment(sd) @request_context def delete_software_deployment(self, cnxt, deployment_id): try: db_api.software_deployment_delete(cnxt, deployment_id) except Exception as ex: logger.warn('delete_software_config db error %s' % str(ex))

of an assembly of other SoftwareConfig resources. These assembled resources
will generally be a mixture of OS::Heat::CloudConfig and

Instead, a server's user_data can contain this resource via get_resource
when user_data_format is SOFTWARE_CONFIG.

commit_message:
A multipart cloud-init resource based on SoftwareConfig

This simple resource allows a multipart mime message to be built out
of an assembly of other SoftwareConfig resources. These assembled resources
will generally be a mixture of OS::Heat::CloudConfig and
OS::Heat::SoftwareConfig resources.

The full multipart content is fetched and stored during resource create.
This is safe since SoftwareConfig data is immutable once created.

Because cloud-init is boot only, this resource won't be used with
a SoftwareDeployment resource, also it will not have inputs or outputs.

Instead, a server's user_data can contain this resource via get_resource
when user_data_format is SOFTWARE_CONFIG.

Implements: blueprint cloud-init-resource

Change-Id: Id72f6ccb6802d654a1dec31f37fb0bcab0e36843

added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import email from email.mime.multipart import MIMEMultipart from email.mime.text import MIMEText import os from heat.engine import constraints from heat.engine import properties from heat.engine.resources.software_config import software_config class MultipartMime(software_config.SoftwareConfig): ''' A resource which assembles a collection of software configurations as a multi-part mime message. Any configuration which is itself a multi-part message will be broken into parts and those parts appended to this message. ''' PROPERTIES = ( PARTS, CONFIG_ID, FILENAME, TYPE, SUBTYPE ) = ( 'parts', 'config_id', 'filename', 'type', 'subtype' ) TYPES = ( TEXT, MULTIPART ) = ( 'text', 'multipart' ) properties_schema = { PARTS: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.LIST, _('Parts belonging to this messsage.'), default=[], schema=properties.Schema( properties.Schema.MAP, schema={ CONFIG_ID: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Content of part to attach.'), required=True ), FILENAME: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Optional filename to associate with part') ), TYPE: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Whether the part content is text or multitype'), default=TEXT, constraints=[constraints.AllowedValues(TYPES)] ), SUBTYPE: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Optional subtype to specify with the type') ), } ) ) } message = None def handle_create(self): props = {self.NAME: self.physical_resource_name()} props[self.CONFIG] = self.get_message() sc = self.heat().software_configs.create(**props) self.resource_id_set(sc.id) def get_message(self): if self.message: return self.message subparts = [] for item in self.properties.get(self.PARTS): config_id = item.get(self.CONFIG_ID) filename = item.get(self.FILENAME, '') subtype = item.get(self.SUBTYPE, '') part_type = item.get(self.TYPE, self.TEXT) sc = self.heat().software_configs.get(config_id) part = sc.config if part_type == self.MULTIPART: self._append_multiparts(subparts, part) else: self._append_part(subparts, part, subtype, filename) mime_blob = MIMEMultipart(_subparts=subparts) self.message = mime_blob.as_string() return self.message @staticmethod def _append_multiparts(subparts, multi_part): multi_parts = email.message_from_string(multi_part) if not multi_parts or not multi_parts.is_multipart(): return for part in multi_parts.get_payload(): MultipartMime._append_part( subparts, part.get_payload(), part.get_content_subtype(), part.get_filename()) @staticmethod def _append_part(subparts, part, subtype, filename): if not subtype and filename: subtype = os.path.splitext(filename)[0] msg = MultipartMime._create_message(part, subtype, filename) subparts.append(msg) @staticmethod def _create_message(part, subtype, filename): msg = MIMEText(part, _subtype=subtype) if filename: msg.add_header('Content-Disposition', 'attachment', filename=filename) return msg def resource_mapping(): return { 'OS::Heat::MultipartMime': MultipartMime, }

subject: Fix test case hidden by catch-all exception
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-03 08:13:04.000000000', 'files': ['keystone/tests/test_notifications.py', 'keystone/notifications.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/f9918aa467bf2c402104c1e6cd3621d1db577b1a', 'message': "Fix test case hidden by catch-all exception

To prevent a notification failure causing a global failure of keystone
to perform operations there is a catch all exception handler around the
notifications code.

In the case of one of our tests there was an issuing with stubbing such
that the mocked function was never actually being called and the
exception handler was masking the problem.

Fix the error to make sure it's called and fix the test that
subsequently fails.

Change-Id: I79420bbecf9d47d1d6bb175bec202ec2d9d8a113
Blueprint: oslo-messaging
"}]
commit_message:
Fix test case hidden by catch-all exception

To prevent a notification failure causing a global failure of keystone
to perform operations there is a catch all exception handler around the
notifications code.

In the case of one of our tests there was an issuing with stubbing such
that the mocked function was never actually being called and the
exception handler was masking the problem.

Fix the error to make sure it's called and fix the test that
subsequently fails.

Change-Id: I79420bbecf9d47d1d6bb175bec202ec2d9d8a113
Blueprint: oslo-messaging

commit_message:
Add instance_get_active_by_window_joined to InstanceList

This is needed to remove get_active_by_window from nova compute API and
allow us to make the simple_tenant_usage API use Flavor objects.

Related to blueprint compute-manager-objects

Change-Id: I93354db2775f08346f9b812f1f1e78a4050efd4a

commit_message:
Store files in the raw_template table

With the get_files intrinsic function, the files data will need to be
available at any time. This change adds a files column to the raw_template
table and saves/loads files from Template class.

Change-Id: I9fd705326ecfe7ca9e00624c67e7dd1965f95a96

Change-Id: I1dfdf68e75975dcc48af1ca10b26ccf8d1f6734b

commit_message:
Fake stack creation

To get this to work do the following:
env.yaml
"
resource_registry:
        'AWS::*': 'Fake::*'
"
heat stack-create faker -e env.yaml -u <templete> -P <what ever params>

Change-Id: I1dfdf68e75975dcc48af1ca10b26ccf8d1f6734b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/57/36157/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import random from heat.engine import resource from heat.openstack.common import log from heat.openstack.common import uuidutils LOG = log.getLogger(__name__) class ChocChipCookie(object): maxes = {'CREATE': {'AWS::EC2::Instance': 6, 'AWS::EC2::Volume': 3, 'AWS::EC2::VolumeAttachment': 3, 'AWS::CloudFormation::WaitCondition': 20}, 'DELETE': {'AWS::EC2::Instance': 3, 'AWS::EC2::Volume': 3, 'AWS::EC2::VolumeAttachment': 2, 'AWS::CloudFormation::WaitCondition': 1}, 'UPDATE': {}, 'SUSPEND': {}, 'RESUME': {}, } def __init__(self, name, res_type, action): self.id = uuidutils.generate_uuid() self.name = name self.res_type = res_type self.action = action mad_max = self.maxes[action].get(res_type, 1) self.count_down = random.randint(1, mad_max) def get_result(self): self.count_down -= 1 LOG.info('check_%s_complete(%s) %d' % (self.action, self.name, self.count_down)) return self.count_down <= 1 class FakeResource(resource.Resource): def __init__(self, name, json_snippet, stack): cls_facade = resource.get_class(json_snippet['Type']) self.properties_schema = cls_facade.properties_schema self.attributes_schema = cls_facade.attributes_schema super(FakeResource, self).__init__(name, json_snippet, stack) if json_snippet['Type'] == 'AWS::CloudWatch::Alarm': self.strict_dependency = False def handle_create(self): cookie = ChocChipCookie(self.name, self.type, self.stack.CREATE) self.resource_id_set(cookie.id) LOG.info('handle_create(%s)' % str(self)) return cookie def check_create_complete(self, cookie): return cookie.get_result() def handle_update(self, after, tmpl_diff, prop_diff): LOG.info('handle_update(%s)' % str(self)) return ChocChipCookie(self.name, self.type, self.stack.UPDATE) def check_update_complete(self, cookie): return cookie.get_result() def handle_delete(self): LOG.info('handle_delete(%s)' % str(self)) return ChocChipCookie(self.name, self.type, self.stack.DELETE) def check_delete_complete(self, cookie): return cookie.get_result() def handle_suspend(self): LOG.info('handle_suspend(%s)' % str(self)) return ChocChipCookie(self.name, self.type, self.stack.SUSPEND) def handle_resume(self): LOG.info('handle_resume(%s)' % str(self)) return ChocChipCookie(self.name, self.type, self.stack.RESUME) def _resolve_attribute(self, name): res = '%s:att:%s' % (self.json_snippet['Type'], name) LOG.info('%s._resolve_attribute(%s) == %s' % (self.name, name, res)) return unicode(res) def resource_mapping(): return { 'Fake::EC2::Instance': FakeResource, 'Fake::ElasticLoadBalancing::LoadBalancer': FakeResource, 'Fake::RDS::DBInstance': FakeResource, 'Fake::CloudFormation::Stack': FakeResource, 'Fake::CloudFormation::WaitConditionHandle': FakeResource, 'Fake::CloudFormation::WaitCondition': FakeResource, 'Fake::IAM::User': FakeResource, 'Fake::IAM::AccessKey': FakeResource, 'Fake::CloudWatch::Alarm': FakeResource, 'Fake::EC2::SecurityGroup': FakeResource, 'Fake::EC2::VolumeAttachment': FakeResource, 'Fake::EC2::Volume': FakeResource, 'Fake::EC2::EIPAssociation': FakeResource, 'Fake::EC2::EIP': FakeResource, 'Fake::AutoScaling::AutoScalingGroup': FakeResource, 'Fake::AutoScaling::LaunchConfiguration': FakeResource, 'Fake::AutoScaling::ScalingPolicy': FakeResource, }

added_lines: #!/usr/bin/python import json import subprocess import zlib from keystoneclient.common import cms signing_cert_file_name = 'certs/signing_cert.pem' signing_key_file_name = 'private/signing_key.pem' for name in ["auth_token_revoked", "auth_token_unscoped", "auth_token_scoped", "auth_token_scoped_expired", "auth_v3_token_scoped", "auth_v3_token_revoked"]: try: json_file="cms/%s.json" % name z_json_file="cms/%s_z.json" % name f = open(json_file, 'r') string_data = f.read() f.close() token_data = json.loads(string_data) text = "zlib:"+ zlib.compress(json.dumps(token_data).encode('utf-8'), 6) signed = cms.cms_sign_text(text, signing_cert_file_name, signing_key_file_name) f = open(z_json_file, 'w') f.write(signed) f.close() except Exception as e: print (e) print (name + " failed") print ('done')

commit_message:
Correctly call client inits from test_multi_backend

This commit fixes the client init calls in setUpClass for
test_mult_backend. Since this doesn't run in the gate it slipped through
the massive config refactor.

Closes-Bug: #1276215

Change-Id: Ibcd521a5b5c3f4d755387b29ee73dcc042c44fa0

subject: Resource type for software configuration
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-18 04:21:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/c4402521352710db206e069000332ebe783c51b6', 'message': 'Resource type for software configuration

    Implementation of the SoftwareConfig resource. Some notes on the implementation:
    * This is a simple wrapper over the REST API, and is essentially
      just for defining data which gets stored.
    * SoftwareConfig will always be UpdateReplace, and the REST entity
      is immutable.
    * OS::Heat::SoftwareConfig will sometimes be used in a template directly
      and sometimes inside a resource provider template which
      defines CM-tool specific properties and aggregates the result into
      the OS::Heat::SoftwareConfig config property.

    This is a POC change which currently lacks tests.

    partial blueprint: hot-software-config

Change-Id: I7350c31ec59d152751c6aa7d811a91e1df62e89d

commit_message:
Resource type for software configuration

    Implementation of the SoftwareConfig resource. Some notes on the implementation:
    * This is a simple wrapper over the REST API, and is essentially
      just for defining data which gets stored.
    * SoftwareConfig will always be UpdateReplace, and the REST entity
      is immutable.
    * OS::Heat::SoftwareConfig will sometimes be used in a template directly
      and sometimes inside a resource provider template which
      defines CM-tool specific properties and aggregates the result into
      the OS::Heat::SoftwareConfig config property.

Implements: blueprint hot-software-config

Change-Id: I7350c31ec59d152751c6aa7d811a91e1df62e89d

commit_message:
Add rules to be a required field for mapping schema

Previously the mapping schema would have validated a mapping
reference that had no rules key. This patch enforces that a rules
key be present.
I also removed the `name` key from a fixture, note that the name
key would not have made the schema fail.

bp mapping-distributed-admin

Change-Id: I64cb8a3333fe9a9372262b490348d52d1373dbb0

subject: Grants DB access to Users in Instance create API
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-24 18:14:40.000000000', 'files': ['troveclient/v1/shell.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-troveclient/commit/029edd779259b855fd6741463c6c4f9d3245f217', 'message': 'Grants DB access to Users in Instance create API

Reasons:
- When database and users are provided as arguments, created users do not
  get access on suggested databases in cli instance create command.
- This was happening because database was not passed along with user info.

Changes:
- Concatenated the database information with the user info.

Change-Id: I3475f0eab1201b963bb32b2155c175a9483ef92f
Closes-Bug: #1272421
'}]
commit_message:
Grants DB access to Users in Instance create API

Reasons:
- When database and users are provided as arguments, created users do not
  get access on suggested databases in cli instance create command.
- This was happening because database was not passed along with user info.

Changes:
- Concatenated the database information with the user info.

Change-Id: I3475f0eab1201b963bb32b2155c175a9483ef92f
Closes-Bug: #1272421
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-troveclient refs/changes/83/68983/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: users = [{'name': n, 'password': p, 'databases': databases} for (n, p) in
deleted_lines: users = [{'name': n, 'password': p} for (n, p) in

subject: Let swift-object-info skip etag verification
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-16 20:57:14.000000000', 'files': ['bin/swift-object-info'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/92fc917b4b753f95f6c950037b2cb5daabf11706', 'message': 'Let swift-object-info skip etag verification

Now swift-object-info has a "-n" option that will cause the etag
verification to be skipped; on large objects, the etag verification
takes the vast majority of the runtime, and sometimes you just want to
know which account owns the 5 GB monstrosity without waiting around while
its checksum is verified.

Change-Id: Id284570633eb7b98046cdb948d7c37a152de1195
'}]
commit_message:
Let swift-object-info skip etag verification

Now swift-object-info has a "-n" option that will cause the etag
verification to be skipped; on large objects, the etag verification
takes the vast majority of the runtime, and sometimes you just want to
know which account owns the 5 GB monstrosity without waiting around while
its checksum is verified.

Change-Id: Id284570633eb7b98046cdb948d7c37a152de1195
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/96/67296/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import osfrom optparse import OptionParser def print_object_info(datafile, check_etag=True): file_len = None if check_etag: h = md5() file_len = 0 while True: data = fp.read(64 * 1024) if not data: break h.update(data) file_len += len(data) h = h.hexdigest() if etag: if h == etag: print 'ETag: %s (valid)' % etag else: print "Etag: %s doesn't match file hash of %s!" % (etag, h) else: print 'ETag: Not found in metadata' else: print 'ETag: %s (not checked)' % etag file_len = os.fstat(fp.fileno()).st_size if __name__ == '__main__': parser = OptionParser() parser.set_defaults(check_etag=True) parser.add_option( '-n', '--no-check-etag', action="store_false", dest="check_etag", help="Don't verify file contents against stored etag") options, args = parser.parse_args() if len(args) < 1: print "Usage: %s [-n] OBJECT_FILE" % sys.argv[0] sys.exit(1) print_object_info(args[0], check_etag=options.check_etag)
deleted_lines: if __name__ == '__main__': if len(sys.argv) <= 1: print "Usage: %s OBJECT_FILE" % sys.argv[0] sys.exit(1) datafile = sys.argv[1] h = md5() file_len = 0 while True: data = fp.read(64 * 1024) if not data: break h.update(data) file_len += len(data) h = h.hexdigest() if etag: if h == etag: print 'ETag: %s (valid)' % etag else: print "Etag: %s doesn't match file hash of %s!" % (etag, h) else: print 'ETag: Not found in metadata'

commit_message:
Sync with commit-id: 9d529dd324d234d7aeaa3e6b4d3ab961f177e2ed

(Pulling from the gate, neutron fail rates are currently too high
to have neutron jobs in the queue.)

added_lines: params = self._sanitize_mod_params(other) unicode_mod = super(Message, self).__mod__(params) params=params, # Save our existing parameters as defaults to protect # ourselves from losing values if we are called through an # (erroneous) chain that builds a valid Message with # arguments, and then does something like "msg % kwds" # where kwds is an empty dictionary. src = {} if isinstance(self.params, dict): src.update(self.params) src.update(dict_param) for key in keys: params[key] = self._copy_param(src[key])

commit_message:
fix grammar error in keystone-manage.rst

remove "through" from "with through the keystone REST api" and fix "keystone" to "Keystone" and "can not" to "cannot".

Change-Id: I1cc74b36cdb7de28be5dc4c3ee74922da8020804
Closes-Bug: #1273862

commit_message:
Replace urllib/urlparse with six.moves.*

urllib and urlparse are divided to different module in Python 3.
Use six.moves.* to make them on Python 2 and Python 3.

Part of blueprint keystone-py3kcompat

Change-Id: I54d322c51f0f87e3ec00c69016251d6ea5015adb

commit_message:
LVM: remove redundant casts to float

The vg_free_space field is always assigned a float, so additional casts
are not necessary.

commit_message:
Forbid availability_zone None in aggregate Nova API

In aggregate API, argument "availability_zone" became optional in the request.
Fixed tempest code same as nova.

Change-Id: I73f42c6c069a9bc6318ac3bac5ec94b61c65ecaf
Related-bug: #1252177

commit_message:
Set SCSI as the default cdrom bus for PowerKVM

Set the default cdrom bus to scsi when the guest architecture is
ppc64 and the hypervisor is kvm|qemu. Checks the arch from
image_meta. Fallback to host arch if arch is not present in the
metadata associated with the image.

KVM unit tests without image_meta unified in a loop.

Change-Id: I62d1490ee8c9ba45a087f934342f14386ddb7cb2

commit_message:
Adding support for incremental backups

* Adds a parent argument to backup-create.
* Adds parent_id to the backup create body if present.

Implements: blueprint incremental-backups

Change-Id: I76f720ae4eadf2a1977c4c2cbf286db4db079b63

commit_message:
Add the alembic migration framework

This includes a new binary "solum-db-manage".

Change-Id: I55910c3b4c02ea89159e28266cb9927cbfbdc5a6

added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import sqlalchemy def upgrade(migrate_engine): meta = sqlalchemy.MetaData() meta.bind = migrate_engine application = sqlalchemy.Table( 'application', meta, sqlalchemy.Column('id', sqlalchemy.Integer, primary_key=True, nullable=False), sqlalchemy.Column('created_at', sqlalchemy.DateTime), sqlalchemy.Column('updated_at', sqlalchemy.DateTime), mysql_engine='InnoDB', mysql_charset='utf8' ) try: application.create() except Exception: meta.drop_all(tables=[application]) raise def downgrade(migrate_engine): raise NotImplementedError('Database downgrade not supported - ' 'would drop all tables')

commit_message:
Clean up docstring in db.sqlalchemy.session

When generating the docs, a couple of warnings were generated for
invalid RST in the module-level docstring for
db.sqlalchemy.session. This change cleans up the docstring.

Change-Id: Id08c876c6698b4ef329247c1d034033f0bfa86cb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/32/70032/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * Call `set_defaults()` with the minimal of the following kwargs: ``sql_connection``, ``sqlite_db`` Example: .. code:: python* Don't use them explicitly; this is like running with ``AUTOCOMMIT=1``. `model_query()` will implicitly use a session when called without one .. note:: Automatic retry will be enabled in a future patch. the code around quotas and `reservation_rollback()`. Examples: .. code:: python* Within the scope of a single method, keep all the reads and writes within the context managed by a single session. In this way, the session's `__exit__` handler will take care of calling `flush()` and `commit()` for you. If using this approach, you should not explicitly call `flush()` or `commit()`. Any error within the context of the session will cause the session to emit a `ROLLBACK`. Database errors like `IntegrityError` will be raised in `session`'s `__exit__` handler, and any try/except within the context managed by `session` will not be triggered. And catching other non-database errors in the session will not trigger the ROLLBACK, so exception handlers should always be outside the session, unless the developer wants to do a partial commit on purpose. If the connection is dropped before this is possible, the database will implicitly roll back the transaction. .. note:: Statements in the session scope will not be automatically retried. do not need to call `model.save()`: .. code:: python .. note:: `update_bar` is a trivially simple example of using ``with session.begin``. Whereas `create_many_foo` is a good example of when a transaction is needed, it is always best to use as few queries as possible. The two queries in `update_bar` can be better expressed using a single query which avoids the need for an explicit transaction. It can be expressed like so: .. code:: python .. note:: `create_duplicate_foo` is a trivially simple example of catching an exception while using ``with session.begin``. The `model.soft_delete()` method works with a single already-fetched entry. `query.soft_delete()` makes only one db request for all entries that correspond to the query. * In almost all cases you should use `query.soft_delete()`. Using `model.soft_delete()`, as in the following .. code:: python

commit_message:
Solum M1 argparse-based Python CLI

* Implements text parsing only, no REST communications
* Implements Application create, delete and list
* Implements Assembly create, delete and list
* Includes some very basic unit tests (expand when REST is added)

Partially implements: blueprint solum-minimal-cli

Change-Id: I0b1431ffb84b0c6ee71640483669bf55401dc81b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-solumclient refs/changes/24/70224/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2014 Rackspace # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. class CommandsBase(object): """Base command parsing class.""" parser = None solum = None def __init__(self, parser): self.parser = parser self._get_global_flags() self.parser.add_argument('action', default='help', help='Action to perform on resource') action = None try: parsed, _ = parser.parse_known_args() action = parsed.action except SystemExit: # Parser has a habit of doing this when an arg is missing. self.parser.print_help() if action in self._actions: try: self.parser.error = self.parser.the_error self._actions[action]() except SystemExit: print(self._actions[action].__doc__) self.parser.print_help() @property def _actions(self): """Action handler""" return dict((attr, getattr(self, attr)) for attr in dir(self) if not attr.startswith('_') and callable(getattr(self, attr))) def _get_global_flags(self): """Get global flags.""" # Good location to add_argument() global options like --verbose pass def help(self): """Print this help message.""" print(self.__doc__) show_help(self._actions, 'actions') def show_help(resources, name='targets or nouns'): """Help screen.""" print("Full list of commands:") print(" app create [--repo=repo_url] [--build=no] plan_name") print(" app delete plan_name") print(" app list") print(" assembly create [--assembly=assembly_name] plan_name") print(" assembly delete assembly_name") print(" assembly list") print("\n") print("Available %s:" % name) for resource in sorted(resources): commands = resources.get(resource) docstring = "<%s %s>" % (name.capitalize(), resource) if commands.__doc__: docstring = commands.__doc__ print("\t%-20s%s" % (resource, docstring))

commit_message:
Update nova.conf.sample for python-keystoneclient 0.5.0

python-keystoneclient 0.5.0 added a new oslo.config option:

 enforce_token_bind=permissive

Change-Id: Ic8c23152c2c4a4f1fb2cda45123874c46b4bf85f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/99/70899/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Used to control the use and type of token binding. Can be # set to: "disabled" to not check token binding. "permissive" # (default) to validate binding information if the bind type # is of a form known to the server and ignore it if not. # "strict" like "permissive" but if the bind type is unknown # the token will be rejected. "required" any form of token # binding is needed to be allowed. Finally the name of a # binding method that must be present in tokens. (string # value) #enforce_token_bind=permissive

commit_message:
Move clear_volume method to volume.utils

clear_volume was almost the same in LVM and BlockDevice drivers.
So it has been moved to utils.

Change-Id: Iadb6b8d01cf500109bb48b0d2c817109918519e0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/49/43449/36 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: vol_size = volume.get('size', volume.get('volume_size', None)) * 1024 volutils.clear_volume(volume, vol_size, self.local_path(volume))
deleted_lines: self.clear_volume(volume) def clear_volume(self, volume): """unprovision old volumes to prevent data leaking between users.""" if self.configuration.volume_clear == 'none': return vol_path = self.local_path(volume) size_in_g = volume.get('size', volume.get('volume_size', None)) if size_in_g is None: LOG.warning(_("Size for volume: %s not found, " "skipping secure delete.") % volume['id']) return size_in_m = self.configuration.volume_clear_size LOG.info(_("Performing secure delete on volume: %s") % volume['id']) if self.configuration.volume_clear == 'zero': if size_in_m == 0: return volutils.copy_volume('/dev/zero', vol_path, size_in_g * 1024, sync=True, execute=self._execute) else: clear_cmd = ['shred', '-n0', '-z', '-s%dMiB' % size_in_m] elif self.configuration.volume_clear == 'shred': clear_cmd = ['shred', '-n3'] if size_in_m: clear_cmd.append('-s%dMiB' % size_in_m) else: LOG.error(_("Error unrecognized volume_clear option: %s"), self.configuration.volume_clear) return clear_cmd.append(vol_path) self._execute(*clear_cmd, run_as_root=True)

commit_message:
Use new images when spawning BM instances.

With nova-BM the TFTP files (kernel and ramdisk) are cached between
instances but disks never are (today). We were treating the disk image
the same way but this is incorrect because its filename is 'disk'
rather than '$uuid' and as such it has to be cleaned out whenever a
deploy request is being processed.

Change-Id: I15c8fc25a4c064341b9f1ed51e6df8d1494fbdff
Co-Authored-By: Robert Collins <rbtcollins@hp.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/60/69060/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Avoid deadlock when stringifying NetworkInfo model
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-04 18:03:19.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/fc3c28efa12e6c66d2b787074f3382031dad4445', 'message': "Avoid deadlock when stringifying NetworkInfo model

In the libvirt driver, we log information about the instance we're
about to generate XML for, which includes a NetworkInfo model. In
reality, this is a NetworkInfoAsyncWrapper which acquires a lock
on the model. Since we're in the middle of a log statement, we also
hold the logging lock. This happens right after we've fired off an
async request to update information about the instance, which first
acquired the network model lock and then acquired the logging lock
to make a seemingly innocuous log record.

The resulting deadlock is fixed by this patch by stringifying the
NetworkInfo object before making the log call in the libvirt
driver.

Change-Id: I81f35197ab7c74daa84fb51fbaa2df28c025da13
Closes-bug: 1276268

commit_message:
Avoid deadlock when stringifying NetworkInfo model

In the libvirt driver, we log information about the instance we're
about to generate XML for, which includes a NetworkInfo model. In
reality, this is a NetworkInfoAsyncWrapper which acquires a lock
on the model. Since we're in the middle of a log statement, we also
hold the logging lock. This happens right after we've fired off an
async request to update information about the instance, which first
acquired the network model lock and then acquired the logging lock
to make a seemingly innocuous log record.

The resulting deadlock is fixed by this patch by stringifying the
NetworkInfo object before making the log call in the libvirt
driver.

Change-Id: I81f35197ab7c74daa84fb51fbaa2df28c025da13
Closes-bug: 1276268
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/46/71046/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Update keystone.conf to use new provider config

This change uses the [token] provider configuration rather than
the deprecated [signing] token_format to select between PKI and UUID
tokens.

Closes-Bug: #1273946
Change-Id: Ia03c2375326c14d4783df3c0774599c795b25cf2

commit_message:
Updates info about booting instances from volume for havana

with links to end user guide
cleanup of xmlns markup
Change-Id: I5102d0e1cbbf0b143352c07b1336f0560f345f54
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/operations-guide refs/changes/51/69051/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>You can attach block storage to instances from the dashboard on the <guilabel>Volumes</guilabel> page. Click the <guibutton>Edit Attachments</guibutton> action next to the volume you wish to attach.</para> <para>To perform this action from command line, run the following command:</para> <para>You can also specify block device mapping at instance boot time through the nova command-line client, as follows:</para> <para>A device name where the volume is attached in the system at <code>/dev/<replaceable>dev_name</replaceable> <literal xmlns:db="http://docbook.org/ns/docbook" <para>The ID of the volume to boot from, as shown in the output of nova volume-list.</para> >snap</literal>, which means that the volume was created from a snapshot, or anything other than <literal >snap</literal> (a blank string is valid). In the example above, the volume was not created from a snapshot, so we leave this field blank in our example below.</para> <para>The size of the volume, in GB. It is safe to leave this blank and have the Compute service infer the size.</para> <para>A boolean to indicate whether the volume should be deleted when the instance is terminated. True can be specified as <literal >1</literal>. False can be specified as <literal >0</literal>.</para> <para>If you have previously prepared the block storage with a bootable file system image it is even possible to boot from persistent block storage. The following example will attempt boot from volume with ID=<literal>13</literal>, it does not delete on terminate. Replace the <literal>--key-name</literal> with a valid keypair <para>Read more detailed instructions for launching an instance from a bootable volume in the <link xlink:href="http://docs.openstack.org/user-guide/content/boot_from_volume.html" >OpenStack End User Guide</link>.</para> <para>To boot normally from an image and attach block storage, map to a device other than vda. You can find instructions for launching an instance and attaching a volume to the instance, copying the image to the attached volume in the <link xlink:href="http://docs.openstack.org/user-guide/content/dashboard_launch_instances_from_volume.html" >OpenStack End User Guide</link>.</para>
deleted_lines: <para>You can attach block storage to instances from the dashboard on the <guilabel>Volumes</guilabel> page. Click the <guibutton>Edit Attachments</guibutton> action next to the volume you wish to attach.</para> <para>To perform this action from command line, run the following command:</para> <para>You can also specify block device mapping at instance boot time through the nova command-line client, as follows:</para> <para>A device name where the volume is attached in the system at <code>/dev/<replaceable>dev_name</replaceable> <literal xmlns:db="http://docbook.org/ns/docbook" <para>The ID of the volume to boot from, as shown in the output of nova volume-list.</para> >snap</literal>, which means that the volume was created from a snapshot, or anything other than <literal >snap</literal> (a blank string is valid). In the example above, the volume was not created from a snapshot, so we leave this field blank in our example below.</para> <para>The size of the volume, in GB. It is safe to leave this blank and have the Compute service infer the size.</para> <para>A boolean to indicate whether the volume should be deleted when the instance is terminated. True can be specified as <literal >1</literal>. False can be specified as <literal >0</literal>.</para> <para>If you have previously prepared the block storage with a bootable file system image it is even possible to boot from persistent block storage. The following example will attempt boot from volume with ID=<literal xmlns:db="http://docbook.org/ns/docbook">13</literal>, it does not delete on terminate. Replace the <literal xmlns:db="http://docbook.org/ns/docbook" >--key-name</literal> with a valid keypair <para>Because of bug <link xlink:title="OpenStack Image Service" xlink:href="https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1163566" >1163566</link> (https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1163566) you must specify an image when booting from a volume in Horizon, even though this image is not used.</para> <para>To boot normally from an image and attach block storage, map to a device other than vda.</para>

commit_message:
Added get_migrate_snapshot_name

Added get_migrate_snapshot_name to utils and updated
changelog of Nexenta iSCSI driver

Change-Id: I80a34b5c07906b55764e04d6b22240aac3fe6c1a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/90/62790/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_migrate_snapshot_name(volume): """Return name for snapshot that will be used to migrate the volume.""" return 'cinder-migrate-snapshot-%(id)s' % volume

commit_message:
Add attribute and configuration for show_image_direct_url

- Add default["openstack"]["image"]["api"]["show_image_direct_url"]
  which defaults to "False"
- Add option into glance-api.conf.erb
- Added test for show_image_direct_url setting
- Adjusted README to reference attribute

Change-Id: I83cd13db1d102118d696d371d94197044abf8e94
Closes-Bug: #1274960
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-image refs/changes/57/70357/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Return the URL that references where the data is stored on the backend. default["openstack"]["image"]["api"]["show_image_direct_url"] = "False"

commit_message:
Add attribute for notification_driver

- Add default ['openstack']['block-storage']['notification_driver'] attributes
- Value defaults to the same as before, so no change, but attribute can
  be overridden.
- Add test for the attribute
- Add README.md entry for the attribute

Change-Id: I3ee6f044a0d9d7a46f5e0225ae440fac4f9255a3
Closes-Bug: #1275714
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-block-storage refs/changes/04/70704/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * `openstack["block-storage"]["notification_driver"]` - Set the notification driver to be used (default to cinder.openstack.common.notifier.rpc_notifier)

commit_message:
Handle translations

Add a new option -l LANGUAGE to build and publish localized content
that is in generated/$LANGUAGE and copy content to
publish_docs/$LANGUAGE.

Add new option --only-book to build only specific manual.

Read gerrit-doc.properties if exists to pass values to maven.

Change-Id: I6a07fe02428679d0e5e00a4d67f1b11d9c85b262
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-doc-tools refs/changes/77/71077/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Force the validation of all files and build all books. Show help message and exit. Do not exit on failures. **--language LANGUAGE, -l LANGUAGE** Build translated manual for language in path generate/$LANGUAGE .
deleted_lines: Force the validation of all files and build all books. Show help message and exit. Do not exit on failures.

commit_message:
Shelve: The snapshot should be removed when delete instance.

When deleting a vm with state "shelved" or "shelved-offloaded",
the vm's snapshot like shelved image should also be removed.

Change-Id: Ie9b0f8dec8f85351ef188f70e0fe9414e332aafe
Closes-Bug: #1259462
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/62/61462/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # At these states an instance has a snapshot associate. if instance['vm_state'] in (vm_states.SHELVED, vm_states.SHELVED_OFFLOADED): try: snapshot_id = instance.system_metadata.get('shelved_image_id') LOG.info(_("Working on deleting snapshot %s " "from shelved instance..."), snapshot_id) self.image_service.delete(context, snapshot_id) except Exception as exc: LOG.warn(_("Failed to delete snapshot " "from shelved instance (s)."), exc)

commit_message:
Fix numbering of steps in proxy section of install_multinode

Steps were numbered 1, 2, (note reset), 1, 2, etc. Then a user says:
"I'm on Step 2 in Proxy section, er..."

See a bug, fix a bug.

Change-Id: If6f32b3a33e1070e705812df7ab299e6736c9806

commit_message:
Make the dispatcher responsible to listen()

The dispatcher is now responsible to configure and to get the listener from
the transport.

The server just ask to the dispatcher to build and return a configured
listener for a provider transport.

Partial implements blueprint notification-subscriber-server

Change-Id: I4a6d9620b8239f6d377bc5788b8a90a860b2f02c

commit_message:
Allow fake driver to consume multiple topics

This patch allow the fake driver to comsume multiple topics
with one listener.

Partial implements blueprint notification-subscriber-server

Change-Id: Ib52dc181e10b487854fbb398eda9f758232a1251
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/15/59715/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def __init__(self, listener, ctxt, message, raw_message, reply_q, topic, target): self._topic = topic self._topic, self.ctxt, self.message, self._target.server, self._target.fanout, self._reply_q) self._consumers = [] def declare_consumer(self, target, topic, server=None): self._consumers.append((target, topic, server)) for target, topic, server in self._consumers: (ctxt, message, reply_q) = self._exchange.poll(topic, server) if message is not None: message = FakeIncomingMessage(self, ctxt, message, message, reply_q, topic, target) message.acknowledge() return message def poll(self, topic, server=None): with self._queues_lock: if server: queue = self._get_server_queue(topic, server) else: queue = self._get_topic_queue(topic) listener = FakeListener(self, target, exchange) listener.declare_consumer(target, target.topic, target.server) listener.declare_consumer(target, target.topic) return listener
deleted_lines: def __init__(self, listener, ctxt, message, raw_message, reply_q, target): self._target.topic, self.ctxt, self.message, server=self._target.server, fanout=self._target.fanout, reply_q=self._reply_q) (ctxt, message, reply_q) = self._exchange.poll(self.target) if message is not None: message = FakeIncomingMessage(self, ctxt, message, message, reply_q, self.target) message.acknowledge() return message def poll(self, target): with self._queues_lock: queue = self._get_server_queue(target.topic, target.server) if not queue: queue = self._get_topic_queue(target.topic) return FakeListener(self, target, exchange)

commit_message:
Provide explicit image create value in Registry v2 Client test

Assign an explicit created_at datetime value to image db fixtures,
it be used to fixes race condition in Registry v2 Client test cases.

Closes-Bug: #1272136
Change-Id: Ib9f1c7072c6ac828479c6a2e5bddd0f3ad057653
Signed-off-by: Zhi Yan Liu <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>

commit_message:
Removed duplicated function to create a swap fs

The mkfs() function in common/utils.py already can be used to create
a swap fs on a device, so there's no need to create another one in the
deploy_utils.py file.

Change-Id: I0e1983d53b43d69b350cff462e975984ce2d86c9

commit_message:
Add optional-requirements.txt

While 'optional requirements' phrase is somewhat self-contradicting,
that's what we really have: requirements of optional (pluggable) parts
of TaskFlow are optional in the sense that one can use TaskFlow
without them.

This change puts all such requirements into optional-requirements.txt to
have all them documented in one place, uses that file to list deps for
default python 2.7 test environment.

Change-Id: Ibeeb6ac68247697790cbc2a2c24d2e9f59a4479c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/26/70926/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Testing and requirements ------------------------ ### Requirements Because TaskFlow has many optional (pluggable) parts like persistence backends and engines, we decided to split our requirements into two parts: - things that are absolutely required by TaskFlow (you can't use TaskFlow without them) are put to `requirements.txt`; - things that are required by some optional part of TaskFlow (you can use TaskFlow without them) are put to `optional-requirements.txt`; if you want to use the feature in question, you should add that requirements to your project or environment; - as usual, things that required only for running tests are put to `test-requirements.txt`. ### Tox.ini Our tox.ini describes several test environments that allow to test TaskFlow with different python versions and sets of requirements installed.

commit_message:
Change the role order in os-network

The migerate network database in openstack-network::server depends on
the network plugin package should be installed first, so I move the
os-network-server to the end of run list.

Closes-Bug: #1270708

Change-Id: I0ebc0c7d30dc2132e36eda0ae613e4f92f24361b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-chef-repo refs/changes/08/67808/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Replace CONF.set_default with self.config

There is special method in ironic test base class dedicated to
override config options. This patch replaces explicit CONF calls
in unit tests by this method.

Change-Id: I439d26954e013fa6baa20538aa11610ca2313679

commit_message:
Add support for image size in v2 api upload

Some backend stores e.g. RBD, will fail if told to create an
image without a valid size (RBD will fail to write to a zero-size
image). Here we add support to allow the image size to be provided
when doing an upload. The result is that the upload content-length
will be set if available either from checking the supplied file
object or as provided by user.

Closes-Bug: 1220197
Change-Id: Ia1f2ea5680a139750d931591949b3e0058148b4b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-glanceclient refs/changes/59/44859/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Use Resource() class from common Oslo code

In the process of unification of the clients code we should
reuse common functionality from Oslo. Resource() class from trove
duplicates Oslo funclionality, so we replace it with inheritance

Related to blueprint common-client-library-2

Change-Id: I9809bd3036a5b544b8ff011432f64dc5af793f61

commit_message:
Support Extensions to Trove Client

extensions on the contrib path (i.e. troveclient/v1/contrib/*.py),
extensions on the python path that follow the naming convention of
*_python_troveclient_ext, and entry-points will now be discovered
and loaded.

due to the mismatch of the api version and the troveclient
package name, '1.0' vs. '1', the client has been patched to look
for contrib in troveclient/v1 vs. the standard troveclient/v1_0

Change-Id: I3ea7bb5ba471b0d421581dcfda7216f429cb7b65
Closes-Bug: #1267577

commit_message:
Add ESX quality warning

In line with the other drivers we've been marking as untested,
this patch marks the ESX driver as "not tested" in the logs to
alert admins to the fact. The VCenter driver is being tested
with minesweeper, and thus does not emit a similar message on
startup.

Change-Id: I9217bab01761f68b716cdce3b21c2653abd9afa1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/50/70850/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _do_quality_warnings(self): LOG.warning(_('The VMware ESX driver is not tested by the OpenStack ' 'project and thus its quality can not be ensured. For ' 'more information, see: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/' 'HypervisorSupportMatrix')) self._do_quality_warnings() def _do_quality_warnings(self): pass

commit_message:
Add rally use command - part 2

This completes the behaviour of the 'rally use' command.
when the command is called, it creates a file called openrc-{deployid}
in ~/.rally/ which contains instructions to export deployment specific
environment variables

It also creates a symlink ~/.rally/openrc that refers to the latest
deployment called with 'rally use'

It becomes simple to just do 'source ~/.rally/openrc' and then
'nova list'

Implements blueprint: rally-use-command

Change-Id: I51ddfdbf7b8ab41b5b26685dd7b671468d306fe1

commit_message:
Move logging out of BDM attach method

We will want to call attach in code paths other than booting an instance
(attaching a volume to a running instance for example). This patch
moves the boot specific log message out of the attach method.

Change-Id: Id70d3cabdd118ee1879d7b593765a5034a7ec88e

commit_message:
Fix up double mocking of swob.Request.__init__

From Pete Zaitcev's work on PBes (https://review.openstack.org/47713):

  Fixes up a problem with double mocking of Request.__init__, which
  should be seen in stock code as well.

Change-Id: Ibf8103425404b03aaab9a4e97a3a62d0fb8dbb14

commit_message:
LVM: log thin pool name and size upon creation

The thin pool creation size may not be obvious to the user, so a log
message may help alleviate some confusion.

Change-Id: I3a98b610be612a4fb7496a89f9005012c9210bf8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/83/70783/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: LOG.info(_('Created thin pool \'%s\' with size %s of total %sg') % (vg_pool_name, size_str, self.vg_free_space))

subject: Sanify handoff search depth with non-integer replica counts
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-12-20 03:51:58.000000000', 'files': ['test/unit/proxy/controllers/test_obj.py', 'swift/proxy/controllers/obj.py', 'swift/proxy/server.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/cfd9d055a66b975e9e1bd2e08cd38cfc906d3b15', 'message': "Sanify handoff search depth with non-integer replica counts

On GET, the proxy will go search the primary nodes plus some number of
handoffs for the account/container/object before giving up and
returning a 404. That number is, by default, twice the ring's replica
count. This was fine if your ring had an integral number of replicas,
but could lead to some slightly-odd behavior if you have fractional
replicas.

For example, imagine that you have 3.49 replicas in your object ring;
perhaps you're migrating a cluster from 3 replicas to 4, and you're
being smart and doing it a bit at a time.

On an object GET that all the primary nodes 404ed, the proxy would
then compute 2 * 3.49 = 6.98, round it up to 7, and go look at 7
handoff nodes. This is sort of weird; the intent was to look at 6
handoffs for objects with 3 replicas, and 8 handoffs for objects with
4, but the effect is 7 for everybody.

You also get little latency cliffs as you scale up replica counts. If,
instead of 3.49, you had 3.51 replicas, then the proxy would look at 8
handoff nodes in every case [ceil(2 * 3.51) = 8], so there'd be a
small-but-noticeable jump in the time it takes to produce a 404.

The fix is to compute the number of handoffs based on the number of
primary nodes for the partition, not the ring's replica count. This
gets rid of the little latency cliffs and makes the behavior more like
what you get with integral replica counts.

If your ring has an integral number of replicas, there's no behavior
change here.

Change-Id: I50538941e571135299fd6b86ecd9dc780cf649f5
"}]
commit_message:
Sanify handoff search depth with non-integer replica counts

On GET, the proxy will go search the primary nodes plus some number of
handoffs for the account/container/object before giving up and
returning a 404. That number is, by default, twice the ring's replica
count. This was fine if your ring had an integral number of replicas,
but could lead to some slightly-odd behavior if you have fractional
replicas.

For example, imagine that you have 3.49 replicas in your object ring;
perhaps you're migrating a cluster from 3 replicas to 4, and you're
being smart and doing it a bit at a time.

On an object GET that all the primary nodes 404ed, the proxy would
then compute 2 * 3.49 = 6.98, round it up to 7, and go look at 7
handoff nodes. This is sort of weird; the intent was to look at 6
handoffs for objects with 3 replicas, and 8 handoffs for objects with
4, but the effect is 7 for everybody.

You also get little latency cliffs as you scale up replica counts. If,
instead of 3.49, you had 3.51 replicas, then the proxy would look at 8
handoff nodes in every case [ceil(2 * 3.51) = 8], so there'd be a
small-but-noticeable jump in the time it takes to produce a 404.

The fix is to compute the number of handoffs based on the number of
primary nodes for the partition, not the ring's replica count. This
gets rid of the little latency cliffs and makes the behavior more like
what you get with integral replica counts.

If your ring has an integral number of replicas, there's no behavior
change here.

Change-Id: I50538941e571135299fd6b86ecd9dc780cf649f5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/98/63298/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.request_node_count = lambda replicas: value self.request_node_count = lambda replicas: value * replicas self.write_affinity_node_count = lambda replicas: value self.write_affinity_node_count = lambda replicas: value * replicas nodes_left = self.request_node_count(len(primary_nodes))
deleted_lines: self.request_node_count = lambda r: value self.request_node_count = lambda r: value * r.replica_count self.write_affinity_node_count = lambda r: value self.write_affinity_node_count = lambda r: value * r.replica_count nodes_left = self.request_node_count(ring)

commit_message:
Remove unused eventlet/greenlet from qpid/rabbit

Because driver should rely on executor and not directly on eventlet,
delete eventlet/greenlet related code.

qpid/rabbit part.

Change-Id: I20a0850d54b6c6f81957beabb12f7d67f0c1e741

commit_message:
Move scrubber outside the store package

Glance's scrubber was created under the store package because it is
intended to clean up images from stores when `delayed_delete` is
enabled. However, it doesn't really belong there.

Soft delete is a Glance feature that allows images to be deleted
asynchronously as opposed of blocking clients requests during the image
deletion. Therefore, it needs to be store agnostic and live within
Glance's codebase.

Partially-Implements blueprint: create-store-package

Change-Id: I25ddbe1f0f1191f33d814dbae5788da7d511773a

commit_message:
Rename API schema modules with removing "_schema"

The paths of API schema modules include "/schemas" and they show
API schema clearly. It is not necessary to include "_schema" in
module names. This patch renames the modules with removing "_schema"
from module names.

@validaiton.schema() takes 1 parameter, so calling it by name
is excessive. Then, this patch removes the specified argument.

By applying these changes, we can specify API schema module in one
line with @validation.schema().

Partially implements blueprint nova-api-validation-fw

Change-Id: Ia646e1c2466fa0a1418f757a48d2e6b4f84f7c98

commit_message:
Silence commands to echo copyright notices

This patch silences commands that echoed copyright notices to the
devstack logs. The copyright notices are moved to the top of the
file as comments.

Change-Id: I8d474a366af2954c168ba8d07329392f56e8e75a

commit_message:
upload_image.sh to support streamOptimized disks

The current version of the script will use "preallocated" as the
disk type of a stream optimized disk. This needs to be fixed by
introspecting the createType of the vmdk file.

Closes-Bug: #1275993

Change-Id: I98594acecf26dd1164870f43890254a19ef23fe9

commit_message:
Update SolidFire Driver to use cinder's units

The SolidFire driver uses math module and it's own
local GB variable.

This patch just removes that and uses the GiB def
that already exists in cinder.units.

Change-Id: I4fc167bd61dbb609bd325b4a32b120bf55db02fa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/98/70898/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Update keystoneclient to 0.5.0

Deprecating the s3_token middleware in Keystone will require that
keystone uses the 0.5.0 version of python-keystoneclient where the
s3_token middleware lives now.

bp s3-token-to-keystoneclient

Change-Id: I6513ddb5bde3d1414ccb6bbd116510fe14860001
Closes-Bug: #1178741
