 * Introduce a new privileged account header: X-Account-Access-Control
 * Introduce JSON-based version 2 ACL syntax -- see below for discussion
 * Implement account ACL authorization in TempAuth

X-Account-Access-Control Header
-------------------------------

Accounts now have a new privileged header to represent ACLs or any other
form of account-level access control.  The value of the header is an opaque
string to be interpreted by the auth system.  A reference implementation is
given in TempAuth, with the knowledge that historically other auth systems
often use TempAuth as a starting point.  Other auth systems are encouraged
to use compatible header values (JSON-encoded dictionaries) for compatibility.

The reference implementation describes three levels of account access:
"admin", "read-write", and "read-only".  Adding new access control features
in a future patch (e.g. "write-only" account access) will automatically be
forward- and backward-compatible, due to the JSON dictionary header format.

The privileged X-Account-Access-Control header may only be read or written
by a user with "swift_owner" status, traditionally the account owner but
now also any user on the "admin" ACL.

Access Levels:

Read-only access is intended to indicate to the auth system that this
list of identities can read everything (except privileged headers) in
the account.  Specifically, a user with read-only account access can get
a list of containers in the account, list the contents of any container,
retrieve any object, and see the (non-privileged) headers of the
account, any container, or any object.

Read-write access is intended to indicate to the auth system that this
list of identities can read or write (or create) any container.  A user
with read-write account access can create new containers, set any
unprivileged container headers, overwrite objects, delete containers,
etc.  A read-write user can NOT set account headers (or perform any
PUT/POST/DELETE requests on the account).

Admin access is intended to indicate to the auth system that this list of
identities has "swift_owner" privileges.  A user with admin account access
can do anything the account owner can, including setting account headers
and any privileged headers -- and thus changing the value of

admin access to other users.

if it chooses to support its use.  Therefore the above access level
descriptions are necessarily advisory only for other auth systems.

When setting the value of the header, callers are urged to use the new
format_acl() method, described below.

New ACL Format
--------------

The account ACLs introduce a new format for ACLs, rather than reusing the
existing format from X-Container-Read/X-Container-Write.  There are several
reasons for this:
 * Container ACL format does not support Unicode
 * Container ACL format is limited to the length of a single HTTP header
 * Container ACLs have a different structure than account ACLs
  + account ACLs have no concept of referrers or rlistings
  + accounts have additional "admin" access level
  + account access levels are more sensibly structured as admin > rw > ro,
    rather than container ACLs' orthogonal read and write access

In addition, the container ACL syntax is a little clunky, and instead of
propagating the clunk, I'd rather propose a next version and introduce a
means for migration.  The V2 ACL syntax has the following benefits:
 * JSON is a well-known standard syntax with parsers in all languages
 * no artificial value restrictions (you can grant access to a user named
    ".rlistings" if you want)
 * forward and backward compatibility: you may have extraneous keys, but
    your attempt to parse the header won't raise an exception

to the old V1 syntax but tolerate the V2 syntax and can easily be flipped
to default to V2.  I'm not changing the default or adding code to rewrite
V1 ACLs to V2, because this patch has suffered too much scope creep already,
but this seems like a sensible milestone in the migration.

-----------------------------------

PUT/POST/DELETE requests if the user is on the admin or read-write ACL, etc.

add or strip the privileged headers from the responses.  Core Swift (not
the auth system) is responsible for that.

DocImpact: Documentation for the new ACL usage and format appears in
summary form in doc/source/overview_auth.rst, and in more detail in
swift/common/middleware/tempauth.py in the TempAuth class docstring.
I leave it to the Swift doc team to determine whether more is needed.

'}, {'number': 7, 'created': '2014-01-08 21:14:30.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/34951684b599e2d7688fa9688958800876543093', 'message': 'Privileged acct ACL header, new ACL syntax, TempAuth impl.

 * Introduce a new privileged account header: X-Account-Access-Control
 * Introduce JSON-based version 2 ACL syntax -- see below for discussion
 * Implement account ACL authorization in TempAuth

X-Account-Access-Control Header
-------------------------------

Accounts now have a new privileged header to represent ACLs or any other
form of account-level access control.  The value of the header is an opaque
string to be interpreted by the auth system.  A reference implementation is
given in TempAuth, with the knowledge that historically other auth systems
often use TempAuth as a starting point.  Other auth systems are encouraged
to use compatible header values (JSON-encoded dictionaries) for compatibility.

The reference implementation describes three levels of account access:
"admin", "read-write", and "read-only".  Adding new access control features
in a future patch (e.g. "write-only" account access) will automatically be
forward- and backward-compatible, due to the JSON dictionary header format.

The privileged X-Account-Access-Control header may only be read or written
by a user with "swift_owner" status, traditionally the account owner but
now also any user on the "admin" ACL.

Access Levels:

Read-only access is intended to indicate to the auth system that this
list of identities can read everything (except privileged headers) in
the account.  Specifically, a user with read-only account access can get
a list of containers in the account, list the contents of any container,
retrieve any object, and see the (non-privileged) headers of the
account, any container, or any object.

Read-write access is intended to indicate to the auth system that this
list of identities can read or write (or create) any container.  A user
with read-write account access can create new containers, set any
unprivileged container headers, overwrite objects, delete containers,
etc.  A read-write user can NOT set account headers (or perform any
PUT/POST/DELETE requests on the account).

Admin access is intended to indicate to the auth system that this list of
identities has "swift_owner" privileges.  A user with admin account access
can do anything the account owner can, including setting account headers
and any privileged headers -- and thus changing the value of
X-Account-Access-Control and thereby granting read-only, read-write, or
admin access to other users.

The auth system is responsible for making decisions based on this header,
if it chooses to support its use.  Therefore the above access level
descriptions are necessarily advisory only for other auth systems.

When setting the value of the header, callers are urged to use the new
format_acl() method, described below.

New ACL Format
--------------

The account ACLs introduce a new format for ACLs, rather than reusing the
existing format from X-Container-Read/X-Container-Write.  There are several
reasons for this:
 * Container ACL format does not support Unicode
 * Container ACL format is limited to the length of a single HTTP header
 * Container ACLs have a different structure than account ACLs
  + account ACLs have no concept of referrers or rlistings
  + accounts have additional "admin" access level
  + account access levels are more sensibly structured as admin > rw > ro,
    rather than container ACLs' orthogonal read and write access

In addition, the container ACL syntax is a little clunky, and instead of
propagating the clunk, I'd rather propose a next version and introduce a
means for migration.  The V2 ACL syntax has the following benefits:
 * JSON is a well-known standard syntax with parsers in all languages
 * no artificial value restrictions (you can grant access to a user named
    ".rlistings" if you want)
 * forward and backward compatibility: you may have extraneous keys, but
    your attempt to parse the header won't raise an exception

I've introduced hooks in parse_acl and format_acl which currently default
to the old V1 syntax but tolerate the V2 syntax and can easily be flipped
to default to V2.  I'm not changing the default or adding code to rewrite
V1 ACLs to V2, because this patch has suffered too much scope creep already,
but this seems like a sensible milestone in the migration.

TempAuth Account ACL Implementation
-----------------------------------

As stated above, core Swift is responsible for privileging the
X-Account-Access-Control header (making it only accessible to swift_owners),
for translating it to -sysmeta-* headers to trigger persistence by the
account server, and for including the header in the responses to requests
by privileged users.  Core Swift puts no expectation on the *content* of
this header.  Auth systems (including TempAuth) are responsible for
defining the content of the header and taking action based on it.

In addition to the changes described above, this patch defines a format
to be used by TempAuth for these headers in the common.middleware.acl
module, in the methods format_v2_acl() and parse_v2_acl().  This patch
also teaches TempAuth to take action based on the header contents.  TempAuth
now sets swift_owner=True if the user is on the Admin ACL, authorizes
GET/HEAD/OPTIONS requests if the user is on any ACL, authorizes
PUT/POST/DELETE requests if the user is on the admin or read-write ACL, etc.

Note that the action of setting swift_owner=True triggers core Swift to
add or strip the privileged headers from the responses.  Core Swift (not
the auth system) is responsible for that.

DocImpact: Documentation for the new ACL usage and format appears in
summary form in doc/source/overview_auth.rst, and in more detail in
swift/common/middleware/tempauth.py in the TempAuth class docstring.
I leave it to the Swift doc team to determine whether more is needed.

Change-Id: I836a99eaaa6bb0e92dc03e1ca46a474522e6e826

Read-only access is intended to indicate to the auth system that this
list of identities can read everything (except privileged headers) in
the account.  Specifically, a user with read-only account access can get
a list of containers in the account, list the contents of any container,
retrieve any object, and see the (non-privileged) headers of the
account, any container, or any object.

Read-write access is intended to indicate to the auth system that this
list of identities can read or write (or create) any container.  A user
with read-write account access can create new containers, set any
unprivileged container headers, overwrite objects, delete containers,
etc.  A read-write user can NOT set account headers (or perform any
PUT/POST/DELETE requests on the account).

Admin access is intended to indicate to the auth system that this list of
identities has "swift_owner" privileges.  A user with admin account access
can do anything the account owner can, including setting account headers
and any privileged headers -- and thus changing the value of
X-Account-Access-Control and thereby granting read-only, read-write, or
admin access to other users.

The auth system is responsible for making decisions based on this header,
if it chooses to support its use.  Therefore the above access level
descriptions are necessarily advisory only for other auth systems.

When setting the value of the header, callers are urged to use the new
format_acl() method, described below.

New ACL Format
--------------

The account ACLs introduce a new format for ACLs, rather than reusing the
existing format from X-Container-Read/X-Container-Write.  There are several
reasons for this:
 * Container ACL format does not support Unicode
 * Container ACLs have a different structure than account ACLs
  + account ACLs have no concept of referrers or rlistings
  + accounts have additional "admin" access level
  + account access levels are structured as admin > rw > ro, which seems more
    appropriate for how people access accounts, rather than reusing
    container ACLs' orthogonal read and write access

In addition, the container ACL syntax is a bit arbitrary and highly custom,
so instead of parsing additional custom syntax, I'd rather propose a next
version and introduce a means for migration.  The V2 ACL syntax has the
following benefits:
 * JSON is a well-known standard syntax with parsers in all languages
 * no artificial value restrictions (you can grant access to a user named
    ".rlistings" if you want)
 * forward and backward compatibility: you may have extraneous keys, but
    your attempt to parse the header won't raise an exception

I've introduced hooks in parse_acl and format_acl which currently default
to the old V1 syntax but tolerate the V2 syntax and can easily be flipped
to default to V2.  I'm not changing the default or adding code to rewrite
V1 ACLs to V2, because this patch has suffered a lot of scope creep already,
but this seems like a sensible milestone in the migration.

TempAuth Account ACL Implementation
-----------------------------------

As stated above, core Swift is responsible for privileging the
X-Account-Access-Control header (making it only accessible to swift_owners),
for translating it to -sysmeta-* headers to trigger persistence by the
account server, and for including the header in the responses to requests
by privileged users.  Core Swift puts no expectation on the *content* of
this header.  Auth systems (including TempAuth) are responsible for
defining the content of the header and taking action based on it.

In addition to the changes described above, this patch defines a format
to be used by TempAuth for these headers in the common.middleware.acl
module, in the methods format_v2_acl() and parse_v2_acl().  This patch
also teaches TempAuth to take action based on the header contents.  TempAuth
now sets swift_owner=True if the user is on the Admin ACL, authorizes
GET/HEAD/OPTIONS requests if the user is on any ACL, authorizes
PUT/POST/DELETE requests if the user is on the admin or read-write ACL, etc.

Note that the action of setting swift_owner=True triggers core Swift to
add or strip the privileged headers from the responses.  Core Swift (not
the auth system) is responsible for that.

DocImpact: Documentation for the new ACL usage and format appears in
summary form in doc/source/overview_auth.rst, and in more detail in
swift/common/middleware/tempauth.py in the TempAuth class docstring.
I leave it to the Swift doc team to determine whether more is needed.

Change-Id: I836a99eaaa6bb0e92dc03e1ca46a474522e6e826

In addition, the container ACL syntax is a bit arbitrary and highly custom,
so instead of parsing additional custom syntax, I'd rather propose a next
version and introduce a means for migration.  The V2 ACL syntax has the
following benefits:
 * JSON is a well-known standard syntax with parsers in all languages
 * no artificial value restrictions (you can grant access to a user named
    ".rlistings" if you want)
 * forward and backward compatibility: you may have extraneous keys, but
    your attempt to parse the header won't raise an exception

I've introduced hooks in parse_acl and format_acl which currently default
to the old V1 syntax but tolerate the V2 syntax and can easily be flipped
to default to V2.  I'm not changing the default or adding code to rewrite
V1 ACLs to V2, because this patch has suffered a lot of scope creep already,
but this seems like a sensible milestone in the migration.

-----------------------------------

X-Account-Access-Control header (making it only accessible to swift_owners),
for translating it to -sysmeta-* headers to trigger persistence by the
account server, and for including the header in the responses to requests
by privileged users.  Core Swift puts no expectation on the *content* of
this header.  Auth systems (including TempAuth) are responsible for
defining the content of the header and taking action based on it.

In addition to the changes described above, this patch defines a format
to be used by TempAuth for these headers in the common.middleware.acl
module, in the methods format_v2_acl() and parse_v2_acl().  This patch
also teaches TempAuth to take action based on the header contents.  TempAuth
now sets swift_owner=True if the user is on the Admin ACL, authorizes
GET/HEAD/OPTIONS requests if the user is on any ACL, authorizes
PUT/POST/DELETE requests if the user is on the admin or read-write ACL, etc.

Note that the action of setting swift_owner=True triggers core Swift to
add or strip the privileged headers from the responses.  Core Swift (not
the auth system) is responsible for that.

DocImpact: Documentation for the new ACL usage and format appears in
summary form in doc/source/overview_auth.rst, and in more detail in
swift/common/middleware/tempauth.py in the TempAuth class docstring.
I leave it to the Swift doc team to determine whether more is needed.

commit_message:
Privileged acct ACL header, new ACL syntax, TempAuth impl.

 * Introduce a new privileged account header: X-Account-Access-Control
 * Introduce JSON-based version 2 ACL syntax -- see below for discussion
 * Implement account ACL authorization in TempAuth

X-Account-Access-Control Header
-------------------------------

Accounts now have a new privileged header to represent ACLs or any other
form of account-level access control.  The value of the header is an opaque
string to be interpreted by the auth system, but it must be a JSON-encoded
dictionary.  A reference implementation is given in TempAuth, with the
knowledge that historically other auth systems often use TempAuth as a
starting point.

The reference implementation describes three levels of account access:
"admin", "read-write", and "read-only".  Adding new access control
features in a future patch (e.g. "write-only" account access) will
automatically be forward- and backward-compatible, due to the JSON
dictionary header format.

The privileged X-Account-Access-Control header may only be read or written
by a user with "swift_owner" status, traditionally the account owner but
now also any user on the "admin" ACL.

Access Levels:

Read-only access is intended to indicate to the auth system that this
list of identities can read everything (except privileged headers) in
the account.  Specifically, a user with read-only account access can get
a list of containers in the account, list the contents of any container,
retrieve any object, and see the (non-privileged) headers of the
account, any container, or any object.

Read-write access is intended to indicate to the auth system that this
list of identities can read or write (or create) any container.  A user
with read-write account access can create new containers, set any
unprivileged container headers, overwrite objects, delete containers,
etc.  A read-write user can NOT set account headers (or perform any
PUT/POST/DELETE requests on the account).

Admin access is intended to indicate to the auth system that this list of
identities has "swift_owner" privileges.  A user with admin account access
can do anything the account owner can, including setting account headers
and any privileged headers -- and thus changing the value of
X-Account-Access-Control and thereby granting read-only, read-write, or
admin access to other users.

The auth system is responsible for making decisions based on this header,
if it chooses to support its use.  Therefore the above access level
descriptions are necessarily advisory only for other auth systems.

When setting the value of the header, callers are urged to use the new
format_acl() method, described below.

New ACL Format
--------------

The account ACLs introduce a new format for ACLs, rather than reusing the
existing format from X-Container-Read/X-Container-Write.  There are several
reasons for this:
 * Container ACL format does not support Unicode
 * Container ACLs have a different structure than account ACLs
  + account ACLs have no concept of referrers or rlistings
  + accounts have additional "admin" access level
  + account access levels are structured as admin > rw > ro, which seems more
    appropriate for how people access accounts, rather than reusing
    container ACLs' orthogonal read and write access

In addition, the container ACL syntax is a bit arbitrary and highly custom,
so instead of parsing additional custom syntax, I'd rather propose a next
version and introduce a means for migration.  The V2 ACL syntax has the
following benefits:
 * JSON is a well-known standard syntax with parsers in all languages
 * no artificial value restrictions (you can grant access to a user named
    ".rlistings" if you want)
 * forward and backward compatibility: you may have extraneous keys, but
    your attempt to parse the header won't raise an exception

I've introduced hooks in parse_acl and format_acl which currently default
to the old V1 syntax but tolerate the V2 syntax and can easily be flipped
to default to V2.  I'm not changing the default or adding code to rewrite
V1 ACLs to V2, because this patch has suffered a lot of scope creep already,
but this seems like a sensible milestone in the migration.

TempAuth Account ACL Implementation
-----------------------------------

As stated above, core Swift is responsible for privileging the
X-Account-Access-Control header (making it only accessible to swift_owners),
for translating it to -sysmeta-* headers to trigger persistence by the
account server, and for including the header in the responses to requests
by privileged users.  Core Swift puts no expectation on the *content* of
this header.  Auth systems (including TempAuth) are responsible for
defining the content of the header and taking action based on it.

In addition to the changes described above, this patch defines a format
to be used by TempAuth for these headers in the common.middleware.acl
module, in the methods format_v2_acl() and parse_v2_acl().  This patch
also teaches TempAuth to take action based on the header contents.  TempAuth
now sets swift_owner=True if the user is on the Admin ACL, authorizes

PUT/POST/DELETE requests if the user is on the admin or read-write ACL, etc.

Note that the action of setting swift_owner=True triggers core Swift to
add or strip the privileged headers from the responses.  Core Swift (not
the auth system) is responsible for that.

DocImpact: Documentation for the new ACL usage and format appears in
summary form in doc/source/overview_auth.rst, and in more detail in
swift/common/middleware/tempauth.py in the TempAuth class docstring.
I leave it to the Swift doc team to determine whether more is needed.

commit_message:
update build_typeURI to drop query string

capture query string in requestPath attribute. use path sans query
string to build typeURI

Change-Id: Ia4ad4ada6172ad56d2f17665942fb7a767f97c3e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/pycadf refs/changes/56/70856/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: for key in re.split('/', req.path): event.requestPath = req.path_qs
deleted_lines: for key in re.split('/', req.path_qs): event.requestPath = req.path

commit_message:
Refactor task/flow flattening

- Instead of having to pass context data between the
  recursive function calls, create an type/object to hold
  this context data, which also contains the flattening
  functionality itself.
- Allow the flattening functions to be more easily
  extended by having a selection function that matches
  item type to flattening function.
- Add pre/post flattening functions (which can be
  extended/inherited to do different activites as
  needed).

Change-Id: I2f2087097f5934e02d9d775eea709673b63f01b1

added_lines: class FlowFlattener(object): """Flattens a item (a task or flow) into a single execution graph.""" def __init__(self, root, freeze=True): self._root = root self._graph = None self._history = set() self._freeze = bool(freeze) def _flatten(self, item): if id(item) in self._history: raise ValueError("Already flattened item: %s" % (item)) functor = self._match_flattener(item) if not functor: raise TypeError("Unknown type requested to flatten: %r, %s" % (type(item), item)) self._pre_item_flatten(item) graph = functor(item) self._history.add(id(item)) self._post_item_flatten(item, graph) return graph def _match_flattener(self, item): if isinstance(item, lf.Flow): return self._flatten_linear elif isinstance(item, uf.Flow): return self._flatten_unordered elif isinstance(item, gf.Flow): return self._flatten_graph elif isinstance(item, task.BaseTask): return self._flatten_task else: return None def _flatten_linear(self, flow): graph = nx.DiGraph(name=flow.name) previous_nodes = [] for f in flow: subgraph = self._flatten(f) graph = gu.merge_graphs([graph, subgraph]) # Find nodes that have no predecessor, make them have a predecessor # of the previous nodes so that the linearity ordering is # maintained. Find the ones with no successors and use this list # to connect the next subgraph (if any). for n in gu.get_no_predecessors(subgraph): # NOTE(harlowja): give each edge its own copy so that if its # later modified that the same copy isn't modified. graph.add_edges_from(((n2, n, FLATTEN_EDGE_DATA.copy()) for n2 in previous_nodes if not graph.has_edge(n2, n))) # There should always be someone without successors, otherwise we # have a cycle A -> B -> A situation, which should not be possible. previous_nodes = list(gu.get_no_successors(subgraph)) return graph def _flatten_unordered(self, flow): graph = nx.DiGraph(name=flow.name) for f in flow: graph = gu.merge_graphs([graph, self._flatten(f)]) return graph def _flatten_task(self, task): graph = nx.DiGraph(name=task.name) graph.add_node(task) return graph def _flatten_graph(self, flow): graph = nx.DiGraph(name=flow.name) # Flatten all nodes subgraph_map = {} for node in flow.graph.nodes_iter(): subgraph = self._flatten(node) subgraph_map[node] = subgraph graph = gu.merge_graphs([graph, subgraph]) # Reconnect all nodes to there corresponding subgraphs for (u, v) in flow.graph.edges_iter(): # Retain and update the original edge attributes. u_v_attrs = gu.get_edge_attrs(flow.graph, u, v) if not u_v_attrs: u_v_attrs = FLATTEN_EDGE_DATA.copy() else: u_v_attrs.update(FLATTEN_EDGE_DATA) u_no_succ = list(gu.get_no_successors(subgraph_map[u])) # Connect the ones with no predecessors in v to the ones with no # successors in u (thus maintaining the edge dependency). for n in gu.get_no_predecessors(subgraph_map[v]): # NOTE(harlowja): give each edge its own copy so that if it's # later modified that the same copy isn't modified. graph.add_edges_from(((n2, n, copy.deepcopy(u_v_attrs)) for n2 in u_no_succ if not graph.has_edge(n2, n))) return graph def _pre_item_flatten(self, item): pass def _post_item_flatten(self, item, graph): def _pre_flatten(self): self._history.clear() def _post_flatten(self, graph): dup_names = misc.get_duplicate_keys(graph.nodes_iter(), key=lambda node: node.name) if dup_names: dup_names = ', '.join(sorted(dup_names)) raise exceptions.InvariantViolation("Tasks with duplicate names " "found: %s" % (dup_names)) def flatten(self): if self._graph is not None: return self._graph self._pre_flatten() graph = self._flatten(self._root) self._post_flatten(graph) if self._freeze: self._graph = nx.freeze(graph) else: self._graph = graph return self._graph return FlowFlattener(item, freeze=freeze).flatten()

commit_message:
Be more resilent around import/detection/setup errors

It appears that some of our current testr failures
are due to this module not handling exception cases
very well; this is making it hard to debug and hard
to determine what the errors are, so handle more of
the general exceptions better in more of the places
where they are problematic.

Change-Id: I7c71d3a68852c0093f27f3b16d6475cc0a8bf8ef

commit_message:
Add VMware storage backend to location strategy

The store to scheme map used in the location strategy module
doesn't contain the VMware datastore backend.

Change-Id: I5d1faeb464dab79c300a525bab6e7e0ecb4ea489
Closes-Bug: #1275126

mask token values

scramble a percentage of leading and trailing characters for a
provided value to avoid security issues.

commit_message:
Fix editing of systemd files on openSUSE

On openSUSE, we install files under /usr/lib/systemd. As that is
a symlink on Fedora, unconditionally changing the path makes
both work at the same time.

Change-Id: I4c3b843b0a5149f109d7051618038e054438e830

commit_message:
Backport changes for openstack-doc-tools

Copy over changes from master for gating with openstack-doc-tools.

This backports also Change-Id: Iff5409daaa8b6e62ab59902e7c47914540a0321c:
    Do not use ndash in filenames

    Ndashes in filenames will cause problems with some filesystems
    and also showed a bug in pbr when running tox.

    Note that none of these files was actually used.
    There is already a copy without the ndashes in common/figures.

Change-Id: Ic6db63f873d8c9346d38ccceb07afffbc99db32d

Provide for adding a string to /etc/hosts.

This is needed for the test environments that are isolated from the
real network including DNS etc.

subject: allow create credential with the system admin token
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-03 19:13:38.000000000', 'files': ['keystone/common/wsgi.py', 'keystone/tests/test_v3_credential.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/f5c8abd171033eea8cbf9ea7f1393780d03f2df0', 'message': "allow create credential with the system admin token

We are looking up trust_id during create credential, which means caller must
use a Keystone-issued token. This is unrealistic as create credential are
often done as part of bootstrap, using the static system admin token.
Furthermore, deployments which using external authorization will break as it
may not have a token_id in the request context.

For the above reasons, we'll skip trust_id lookup if the request token_id is
either absent or it is the static system admin token.

closes bug 1275145

Change-Id: Ic0aaae8b4ac3ac28ae70ea2c8567b556d9d20ec0
"}]
commit_message:
allow create credential with the system admin token

We are looking up trust_id during create credential, which means caller must
use a Keystone-issued token. This is unrealistic as create credential are
often done as part of bootstrap, using the static system admin token.
Furthermore, deployments which using external authorization will break as it
may not have a token_id in the request context.

For the above reasons, we'll skip trust_id lookup if the request token_id is
either absent or it is the static system admin token.

closes bug 1275145

Change-Id: Ic0aaae8b4ac3ac28ae70ea2c8567b556d9d20ec0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/03/70803/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from keystone import configCONF = config.CONF def test_create_credential_with_admin_token(self): # Make sure we can create credential with the static admin token ref = self.new_credential_ref(user_id=self.user['id']) r = self.post( '/credentials', body={'credential': ref}, token=CONF.admin_token) self.assertValidCredentialResponse(r, ref)

commit_message:
Javascript prohibits the use of bitwise operators

    Bitwise operators are very rare in JavaScript programs and
quite often & is simply a mistyped &&.

Implements: blueprint jshint-codestyle

Change-Id: Ib176d811f022782ab68ca97a42946f1aa9fec6cc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/55/65255/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'curly': true, 'bitwise': true

commit_message:
Corrects matching of heat resources status

Reason:
- There is no attribute resource.state instead there is
  resource.resource_status.

Changes:
- Changes resource.state by resource.resource_status.
- The allowed value for successful resource created is CREATE_COMPLETE.

Change-Id: Ie1cce3cba6f19d10e7c3ddbb2389a19baf98d707
Closes-Bug: #1273094

subject: Use ContextFormatter for imparting context info
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-12-23 16:19:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator/commit/8708fd61c55fe19c3f28c72bc7e9de270efacf1d', 'message': "Use ContextFormatter for imparting context info

Currently, we are using a logger instance adapter - ContextAdapter -
for imparting contextual information into log records (e.g. API request
ids). Unfortunately, the way ContextAdapter is applied to logger
instances makes them unusable for 3rd party libraries: there is a
helper factory function in openstack.common.log - getLogger() - which
obtains a logger instance via standard Python interface and wraps it
in a ContextAdapter instance. 3rd party libraries (e.g. SQLAlchemy)
know nothing about oslo-incubator code, so their log records in log
files of OpenStack services won't have request_id value set.

In order to fix this issue we can rely on the fact that all log entries
are propagated up to the root logger. Moving impating of contextual
information into a handler/formatter bound to the root logger, would
allow us to modify log records of 3rd party libraries too.

Closes-Bug: #1263714

Change-Id: Ibe6edf1fcf111481abfd750fcbef89209ee9d615

If logging is configured using a separate configuration file rather
than via project.conf, deployers can use ContextFormatter formatter
provided by openstack.common.log module in order to impart contextual
information into log messages (e.g. request_id), so that it would be
possible to correlate log messages of third-party libraries like e.g.
SQLAlchemy with requests to API services.

Closes-Bug: #1263714

Change-Id: Ibe6edf1fcf111481abfd750fcbef89209ee9d615

commit_message:
Use ContextFormatter for imparting context info

Currently, we are using a logger instance adapter - ContextAdapter -
for imparting contextual information into log records (e.g. API
request ids). Unfortunately, the way ContextAdapter is applied to
logger instances makes them unusable for 3rd party libraries: there
is a helper factory function in openstack.common.log - getLogger() -
which obtains a logger instance via standard Python interface and
wraps it in a ContextAdapter instance. 3rd party libraries (e.g.
SQLAlchemy) know nothing about oslo-incubator code, so their log
records in log files of OpenStack services won't have request_id
value set.

In order to fix this issue we can rely on the fact that all log
entries are propagated up to the root logger. Moving imparting of
contextual information into a handler/formatter bound to the root
logger, would allow us to modify log records of 3rd party libraries
too.

DocImpact

If logging is configured using a separate configuration file rather
than via project.conf, deployers can use ContextFormatter formatter
provided by openstack.common.log module in order to impart contextual
information into log messages (e.g. request_id), so that it would be
possible to correlate log messages of third-party libraries like e.g.
SQLAlchemy with requests to API services.

Closes-Bug: #1263714

Change-Id: Ibe6edf1fcf111481abfd750fcbef89209ee9d615
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/82/63782/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def setup(product_name, version='unknown'): _setup_logging_from_conf(product_name, version)def _setup_logging_from_conf(project='unknown', version='unknown'): handler.setFormatter(ContextFormatter(project=project, version=version, datefmt=datefmt)) def __init__(self, project='unknown', version='unknown', *args, **kwargs): super(ContextFormatter, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs) self.project = project self.version = version # store project info record.project = self.project record.version = self.version # store request info context = getattr(local.store, 'context', None) if context: d = _dictify_context(context) for k, v in d.items(): setattr(record, k, v)

commit_message:
Revert "CSS to fix content appearing below side pane"

The original issue was far less common than the new issue.

Closes-bug: #1273208

This reverts commit f3ca2756cc71412a60c9eff9cf14c15c097f0726

Change-Id: Idb45d36ace000f0e177a72ce9f9b7162450f0651
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/32/70832/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: padding-left: 250px;

Add repo-name to doc-test.conf

Add one more option to doc-test.conf: The name of the repo.

Change-Id: I75f9894074c1d1b6739e2ad1d3c7c7b6b2dcbe46

commit_message:
Add doc-test.conf

This is needed for v0.5 of the doc-tools.

blueprint draft-docs-on-docs-draft

Change-Id: I0a47600d8d8d733765733c265fe0c79f65afb3f2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack-attic/netconn-api refs/changes/07/70807/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: [DEFAULT] repo_name = netconn-api api_site = True # These two options need to come as pairs: book = v1.0 target_dir = target/docbkx/webhelp/openstack-network book = v2.0 target_dir = target/docbkx/webhelp/openstack-network

commit_message:
Remove vi modelines

We don't need to have the vi modelines in each source file,
it can be set in a user's vimrc if required.

Also a check is added to hacking to detect if they are re-added.

Change-Id: I347307a5145b2760c69085b6ca850d6a9137ffc6
Closes-Bug: #1229324
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/63/69263/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add entries from OPS Guide

This adds entries to the openstack-manual glossary that are only
in the OPS Guide glossary.

It also fixes a typo.

Change-Id: I71dae9e52546c3daf2597511160ef553819f5c7a

commit_message:
Minor edits in high availability section

Removes the single usage of hyphenation in "high-availability".
Lowercased "server" usage in "Networking Server" for consistency.

Change-Id: I5a79caf9acb265939a454b379c6d0f61c9f713bd
Partial-Bug: #1217503

commit_message:
adjust typeURI to capture target better

update to fix nova audits.
- change typeURI to record greater depth of api request.
- add custom_actions to allow special case actions based on api
path

Change-Id: I2b33cf8cff796bdb135dd832c23f0e2ffdf90780
blueprint: audit-all-apis

path ends with known custom_action, take action from config; path = req.path[:-1] if req.path.endswith('/') else req.path url_ending = path[path.rfind('/') + 1:] if url_ending in self._MAP.custom_actions: action = self._MAP.custom_actions[url_ending] elif url_ending + '/' + method.lower() in self._MAP.custom_actions: action = self._MAP.custom_actions[url_ending + '/' + method.lower()] elif method == 'POST': if url_ending == 'action': action = taxonomy.ACTION_UPDATE + '/' + body_action elif url_ending not in self._MAP.path_kw: if url_ending in self._MAP.path_kw: type=self._MAP.service_endpoints.get( def _build_typeURI(self, req, service_type): type_uri = '' prev_key = None for key in re.split('/', req.path_qs): if key in self._MAP.path_kw: type_uri += '/' + key elif prev_key in self._MAP.path_kw: type_uri += '/' + self._MAP.path_kw[prev_key] prev_key = key return service_type + type_uri def create_event(self, req, correlation_id): if not self._MAP: self._MAP = _configure_audit_map() elif (self._MAP.default_target_endpoint_type and endp['type'] == self._MAP.default_target_endpoint_type): target_typeURI = (self._build_typeURI(req, service_info.type) if service_info.type != taxonomy.UNKNOWN else service_info.type) target = resource.Resource(typeURI=target_typeURI,

Document auth options in sample config

There was no documentation for the options in the [auth] section
of the sample config file.

Change-Id: I19a18157cfd6d353a6ddfcad8377b835a886c086
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/77/66477/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Defines the authentication method plugins that are available. # This is a comma-separated list of names of the methods that are allowed in # the "methods" field of an authentication request and the external # authentication handler. # If the "external" method is included, then external authentication (via # REMOTE_USER) is enabled. # The other named methods can be used in the "methods" field of the # authentication request. # For each method named, an option in this section with the same name defines # the plugin to use to implement the method. # The plugin to use for each of the methods listed in the "methods" option.

commit_message:
Make the object storage section less Ubuntu centric

The Swift section of the install guide tends to assume that the user
uses Ubuntu. This change provide more information for other
distributions.

backport: havana
Closes-Bug: #1274473
Closes-Bug: #1274405
Change-Id: I1c1fbea43d29724067185e3ab261cd20b2e0ed72

commit_message:
Remove single datastore limitation for VMWARE

The VMWARE driver no longer restricts operators to using one datastore
per cluster.

Change-Id: I1d77c091d8869a2a9b1641babde40ea17e7d4715
Closes-Bug: #1274311
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/52/70552/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: configured for OpenStack.</para>
deleted_lines: configured for OpenStack. Currently, a single data store can be used per cluster. A future Havana stable release will address this temporary limitation.</para>

commit_message:
Configure SELinux to allow HTTP network connection

SELinux requires the httpd_can_network_connect boolean to be set to
allow network connections to the HTTP server.

Change-Id: I07c1a9b94af9e986b63aebdeb0644822d6b7ef3e
Closes-Bug: #1272100

commit_message:
Fix repository and dist-upgrade

apt-get doesn't have dist-update command, replace with correct
dist-upgrade. Also fix incorrect repository address.

Change-Id: Id98add7686dbc7ffa4d4e38dab81bb57c8b059f4
Closes-Bug: #1275304

commit_message:
Don't match commented [DEFAULT]

Class ceilometer::agent::compute fails when there are [DEFAULT] sections
commented. This patch is fixing this issue. For more info check
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1060712

Change-Id: I6d13f780f63af8798d94b49246576d1e144a4540
(cherry picked from commit a46bbc4c5179d4988f4beec0fc548c91300008a2)

commit_message:
CSS to fix content appearing below side pane

Content normally shows up on the right side of the navigation pane.
However, a long dashboard name will cause the content to appear below
the navigation pane.

Currently, the content is set to have left padding of 250px. This is
not ideal as the side-navigation pane may take up more space. I have
included a css fix that will allow the content to float and remain next
to the navigation pane. This solution have been tested in all major
browsers including IE.

Fixed the expanding issue.

Change-Id: Ied5c6085c643eba72a54279ff2e57221ddac76df
Closes-Bug: #1267661

added_lines: nets = [] if network_id in ports.keys(): ports[network_id].append(port) else: ports[network_id] = [ port ] for net_id in net_ids: nets += self._get_available_networks(context, instance['project_id'], net_id) ports_in_network = ports.get(network_id) if ports_in_network: for port in ports_in_network: port_client.update_port(port['id'], port_req_body) touched_port_ids.append(port['id']) # Note(newbie-bug-1187244): I guess we should agree if we limit to disable duplicates by all # means or allow an optional nova config flag to optionally enable network # duplicates rather than always forcing on throwing an exception on duplicates # if net_id in net_ids: # raise exception.NetworkDuplicated(network_id=net_id) if net_id not in net_ids: net_ids.append(net_id)

subject: Pull docker images from global registry
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-31 06:39:12.000000000', 'files': ['lib/nova_plugins/hypervisor-docker', 'tools/docker/install_docker.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/2dac885e6c48989d9a7bc89aca2b69503d2b3399', 'message': "Pull docker images from global registry

The global docker registry is where images are
being built and uploaded. It's effectively docker's
version of, say, 'pip'. The static tarballs are
not only an extra maintenance burden as they're outside
the standard build and publishing process, but are presently
outside the scope of an open development / release
process as well.

While this process does cause some trouble with
network-independence for CI purposes, the fetching
is still done from install-docker.sh; Additionally,
this driver is not currently tested via the community CI effort.

Change-Id: I3ee6bfee9c273cd3aabe1e00a1d1a8856a466189
"}]
commit_message:
Pull docker images from global registry

The global docker registry is where images are
being built and uploaded. It's effectively docker's
version of, say, 'pip'. The static tarballs are
not only an extra maintenance burden as they're outside
the standard build and publishing process, but are presently
outside the scope of an open development / release
process as well.

While this process does cause some trouble with
network-independence for CI purposes, the fetching
is still done from install-docker.sh; Additionally,
this driver is not currently tested via the community CI effort.

Change-Id: I3ee6bfee9c273cd3aabe1e00a1d1a8856a466189

subject: Have ceilometer to respect the keystone settings
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-02 08:40:58.000000000', 'files': ['lib/ceilometer'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/2ed4ae70b820ad3cbd12f2b6c2452ff66005ebaa', 'message': 'Have ceilometer to respect the keystone settings

lib/ceilometer ignored the global settings related to keystone settings.

It can cause issues for example when the keystone does not listen on
127.0.0.1 even in single node deployment.

Change-Id: I6e4654daa2ec624ac11aaf7f49495fcfaa72071d
'}]
commit_message:
Have ceilometer to respect the keystone settings

lib/ceilometer ignored the global settings related to keystone settings.

It can cause issues for example when the keystone does not listen on
127.0.0.1 even in single node deployment.

Change-Id: I6e4654daa2ec624ac11aaf7f49495fcfaa72071d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/68/70568/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: iniset $CEILOMETER_CONF keystone_authtoken auth_host $KEYSTONE_AUTH_HOST iniset $CEILOMETER_CONF keystone_authtoken auth_port $KEYSTONE_AUTH_PORT iniset $CEILOMETER_CONF keystone_authtoken auth_protocol $KEYSTONE_AUTH_PROTOCOL

bash_completion for heat and ceilometer

Installing bash completion for heat and ceilometer by using a
similar way used with other services.

commit_message:
Add additional terms to glossary

Add "active/active" and "active/passive" to glossary.

Change-Id: Ia42dcdbf00563087ed1fc7e5e6e40c6851c60d49
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/70/70570/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <glossterm>active/active configuration</glossterm> <glossdef> <para>In a high availability setup with an active/active configuration, several systems share the load together and if one fails, the load is distributed to the remaining systems. </para> </glossdef> </glossentry> <glossentry> <glossterm>active/passive configuration</glossterm> <glossdef> <para>In a high availability setup with an active/passive configuration, systems are set up to bring additional resources online to replace those that have failed. </para> </glossdef> </glossentry> <glossentry>

commit_message:
revise oauth1 middleware nickname to match docs

doc/source/extensions/oauth1-configuration.rst refers to this middleware
as the `oauth1_extension`.

Change-Id: I474a429c65dd2f41726fdd6f3a922b12995bcd00
Closes-Bug: 1275693

added_lines: [filter:oauth1_extension]

commit_message:
docstring fix

The docstring of class Extended_availability_zone was totally same as
Extended_server_attributes. This patch improves this docstring.

Change-Id: Ifd59d8dd149975c7f2653a0e0effadfc88d119d4

commit_message:
Fix string formatting of exception.NoUniqueMatch message

There is no implicit logger string formatting happening, so
we need to do this on our own.

Change-Id: I13dfb804d55b5ede2987e355f8a932f237b56c56
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/16/67116/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: raise exception.NoUniqueMatch( _("Multiple security groups found matching" " '%s'. Use an ID to be more specific.") % security_group)
deleted_lines: msg = (_("Multiple security groups found matching" " '%s'. Use an ID to be more specific."), security_group) raise exception.NoUniqueMatch(msg)

subject: Fix psutils failing to install for heat-cfntools
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-03 16:59:47.000000000', 'files': ['elements/heat-cfntools/install.d/05-heat-cfntools'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements/commit/8b4c68e8e62b73113f9bcf2411b75fafc09c69ea', 'message': "Fix psutils failing to install for heat-cfntools

Reason: tripleo-image-elements/elements/install.d/05-heat-cfntools
        while run from diskimage-builder's dib-run-parts fails to
        find the Python.h header required while compiling psutil.

Change: Include python-dev package in 05-heat-cfntools

Closes-Bug: #1275662

Change-Id: I7ff4cb1e09047ab4184fd62914b51f3cce068f52
"}]
commit_message:
Fix psutils failing to install for heat-cfntools

Reason: tripleo-image-elements/elements/install.d/05-heat-cfntools
        while run from diskimage-builder's dib-run-parts fails to
        find the Python.h header required while compiling psutil.

Change: Include python-dev package in 05-heat-cfntools

Closes-Bug: #1275662

Change-Id: I7ff4cb1e09047ab4184fd62914b51f3cce068f52
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/69/70769/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: python-pip python-psutil python-virtualenv gcc python-dev

commit_message:
Sync unhandled exception logging change from Oslo

Copying changes from 1 Oslo commit: Ibf00173a07510b2ec0c81a29624004f17810a4e4
This is related to the bug fix for adding error type to unhandled
exception log message.

Change-Id: Ie8af57a148753121f79136af928feb0edaea228b
Closes-Bug: #1265561

commit_message:
Import translations for Havana 2013.2.2 udpate

* Import the latest translations of ~100% completed languages.
  12 translated languages are avaialable.
* Update POT files (English PO file)

This commit is directly proposed to stable/havana branch because
strings are different between stable/havana and master branches.

Change-Id: I117ea214d121d4c70e8f3679c88d0c758c586f99

commit_message:
Invoke setUp() in provider config tests

Invoking setUp() allows the base setUp() to add cleanups.

Closes-bug: #1275789

Change-Id: Ib4835d19a057e99621d23d319225121e955bbe16
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/49/70749/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def setUp(self): self.addCleanup(cfg.CONF.reset)

commit_message:
Remove deprecated cinder::base class

cinder::base class has been deprecated since before 2.0.0 release.

Closes-bug: #1271737
Change-Id: I7116bc200b791be159108642ecff9874ee54cd6b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-cinder refs/changes/06/68506/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # class cinder::base ( $rabbit_password, $sql_connection, $rabbit_host = '127.0.0.1', $rabbit_port = 5672, $rabbit_hosts = undef, $rabbit_virtual_host = '/', $rabbit_userid = 'nova', $package_ensure = 'present', $api_paste_config = '/etc/cinder/api-paste.ini', $verbose = false ) { warning('The cinder::base class is deprecated. Use cinder instead.') class { 'cinder': rabbit_password => $rabbit_password, sql_connection => $sql_connection, rabbit_host => $rabbit_host, rabbit_port => $rabbit_port, rabbit_hosts => $rabbit_hosts, rabbit_virtual_host => $rabbit_virtual_host, rabbit_userid => $rabbit_userid, package_ensure => $package_ensure, api_paste_config => $api_paste_config, verbose => $verbose, } }

commit_message:
Add Neutron support

Currently create instance doesnt work in OS installation with Neutron.
To get it work, additional parameter 'nics' should be specified
in Nova 'create' call.
This change allows user to pass 'nics' parameter when create instance.
Also possible to specify list of network IDs which should be attached
to instance if networks are not specified by user.

Closes-Bug: #1257838

Change-Id: Ifd98a880dfa22e9677e802bcd779acd9146ec671

commit_message:
Fix benchmark.utils.get_from_manager()

* get_from_manager() method should raise exception in case of
unexisting resources. So we will be able to handle this in proper
way and avoid __getitem__ exception.

* Add rally.utils.wait_for_delete() that will update resource
unit it raise excetpion (not found).

* Use rally.utils.wait_for_delete() in all methods that delete
resources

* Add part of missing tests for benchmark.utils methods

Change-Id: If9fed2418c61de9f18023b2d2cc1fd81673d9379
Closes-Bug: #1269307

for i, real_args in enumerate(utils.infinite_run_args(args)): self.assertEqual((i,) + args, real_args) if i == 10: break def test_create_openstack_clients(self): #TODO(boris-42): Implement this method manager._cache(resource) self.assertRaises(exceptions.GetResourceFailure, get_from_manager, resource) def test_get_from_manager_not_found(self): get_from_manager = utils.get_from_manager() manager = mock.MagicMock() resource = fakes.FakeResource(manager=manager, status="ERROR") class NotFoundException(Exception): http_status = 404 manager.get = mock.MagicMock(side_effect=NotFoundException) self.assertRaises(exceptions.GetResourceFailure, get_from_manager, resource) def test_get_from_manager_http_exception(self): get_from_manager = utils.get_from_manager() manager = mock.MagicMock() commit_message:
Update l3_if_downup to eval carrier state when starting

Update l3_if_downup to evaluate the current carrier state when starting.
 if the current state is down, change resource[:wait_carrier_after_ifup]
 to false. This will cause the carrier state check loop to be skipped
 since we know the interface is down already.

Change-Id: If88348affc14236c19d34bb5b46691c940f6bf4b
Closes-bug: #1275132

deleted_lines: begin _rc = File.open("/sys/class/net/#{@resource[:interface]}/carrier", 'r'){ |file| file.read() } rescue _rc = -1 end if _rc.to_i() == 1 elsif _rc.to_i() == -1

commit_message:
Create /var/run/neutron

We configure neutron to use /var/run/neutron, yet that path is not
created by the packaged install, so we need to create it explicitly.
The path must be created at runtime, not build time, since /var/run is
typically tmpfs mounted.

Change-Id: I12c1effa30f98729a77dc2be52a499b6dec23d50

commit_message:
Cleanup rspec tests of nova::compute

Change-Id: I0822ab9e746e3bc19a8e9d8851735657af772dd7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova refs/changes/46/70246/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: shared_examples 'nova-compute' do context 'with default parameters' do it 'installs nova-compute package and service' do should contain_service('nova-compute').with({ :name => platform_params[:nova_compute_service], :ensure => 'stopped', :hasstatus => true, :enable => false }) should contain_package('nova-compute').with({ :name => platform_params[:nova_compute_package] }) it { should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/network_device_mtu').with(:ensure => 'absent') } it { should_not contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/novncproxy_base_url') } end context 'with overridden parameters' do let :params do { :enabled => true, :ensure_package => '2012.1-2', :vncproxy_host => '127.0.0.1', :network_device_mtu => 9999 } it 'installs nova-compute package and service' do should contain_service('nova-compute').with({ :name => platform_params[:nova_compute_service], :ensure => 'running', :hasstatus => true, :enable => true }) should contain_package('nova-compute').with({ :name => platform_params[:nova_compute_package], :ensure => '2012.1-2' }) it 'configures network_device_mtu' do should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/network_device_mtu').with_value('9999') it 'configures vnc in nova.conf' do should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/vnc_enabled').with_value(true) should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/vncserver_proxyclient_address').with_value('127.0.0.1') should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/novncproxy_base_url').with_value( 'http://127.0.0.1:6080/vnc_auto.html' ) context 'with neutron_enabled set to false' do let :params do { :neutron_enabled => false } it 'installs bridge-utils package for nova-network' do should contain_package('bridge-utils').with( :ensure => 'present', :before => 'Nova::Generic_service[compute]' ) end context 'with vnc_enabled set to false' do let :params do { :vnc_enabled => false } end it 'disables vnc in nova.conf' do should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/vnc_enabled').with_value(false) should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/vncserver_proxyclient_address').with_value('127.0.0.1') should_not contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/novncproxy_base_url') end end context 'with force_config_drive parameter set to true' do let :params do { :force_config_drive => true } end it { should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/force_config_drive').with_value(true) } end end context 'on Debian platforms' do let :facts do { :osfamily => 'Debian' } end let :platform_params do { :nova_compute_package => 'nova-compute', :nova_compute_service => 'nova-compute' } end it_behaves_like 'nova-compute' end context 'on RedHat platforms' do let :facts do { :osfamily => 'RedHat' } end let :platform_params do { :nova_compute_package => 'openstack-nova-compute', :nova_compute_service => 'openstack-nova-compute' } end it_behaves_like 'nova-compute'
deleted_lines: describe 'with required params provided' do let :params do { :vncproxy_host => '127.0.0.1', :neutron_enabled => true } end describe 'on debian platforms' do let :facts do { :osfamily => 'Debian' } it { should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/vnc_enabled').with_value(true) } it { should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/vncserver_proxyclient_address').with_value('127.0.0.1') } it { should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/novncproxy_base_url').with_value( 'http://127.0.0.1:6080/vnc_auto.html' ) } it { should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/network_device_mtu').with('ensure' => 'absent') } it { should contain_service('nova-compute').with( 'name' => 'nova-compute', 'ensure' => 'stopped', 'hasstatus' => true, 'enable' => false )} it { should contain_package('nova-compute').with( 'name' => 'nova-compute', 'ensure' => 'present', 'notify' => 'Service[nova-compute]' ) } describe 'with vnc_enabled set to true' do let :params do { :enabled => true, :vncproxy_host => '127.0.0.1' } end it { should contain_service('nova-compute').with( 'name' => 'nova-compute', 'ensure' => 'running', 'hasstatus' => true, 'enable' => true )} describe 'with vnc_enabled set to false' do let :params do {:vnc_enabled => false} end it { should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/vnc_enabled').with_value(false) } it { should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/vncserver_proxyclient_address').with_value('127.0.0.1')} it { should_not contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/novncproxy_base_url') } describe 'with force_config_drive set to true' do let :params do {:force_config_drive => true} end it { should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/force_config_drive').with_value('true') } describe 'with network_device_mtu specified' do let :params do {:network_device_mtu => 9999} end it { should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/network_device_mtu').with_value('9999') } end describe 'with package version' do let :params do {:ensure_package => '2012.1-2'} end it { should contain_package('nova-compute').with( 'ensure' => '2012.1-2' )} describe 'on rhel' do let :facts do { :osfamily => 'RedHat' } it { should contain_service('nova-compute').with( 'name' => 'openstack-nova-compute', 'ensure' => 'stopped', 'hasstatus' => true, 'enable' => false )} it { should contain_package('nova-compute').with_name('openstack-nova-compute') }

proxy' do should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/service_neutron_metadata_proxy').with(:value => false) should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/neutron_metadata_proxy_shared_secret').with(:ensure => 'absent') context 'with overridden parameters' do before do params.merge!({ :enabled => true, :ensure_package => '2012.1-2', :auth_host => '10.0.0.1', :auth_port => 1234, :auth_protocol => 'https', MINUTE)', }) it 'installs nova-api package and service' do should contain_package('nova-api').with( :name => platform_params[:nova_api_package], :ensure => '2012.1-2' ) should defined params for nova.conf and api-paste.ini' do it { should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/ec2_listen').with('value' => '192.168.56.210') } it { should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/osapi_compute_listen').with('value' => '192.168.56.210') } it { should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/metadata_listen').with('value' => '127.0.0.1') } it { should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/osapi_volume_listen').with('value' => '192.168.56.210') } it { should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/use_forwarded_for').with('value' => false) } it { should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/osapi_compute_workers').with('value' => '5') } it { should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/service_neutron_metadata_proxy').with('value' => true) } it { should contain_nova_config('DEFAULT/neutron_metadata_proxy_shared_secret').with('value' => 'secrete') } describe "with auth_admin_prefix_containing incorrect value #{auth_admin_prefix}" do let :params do { :auth_admin_prefix => auth_admin_prefix, :admin_password => 'dummy' } describe 'on rhel' do let :facts do { :osfamily => 'RedHat' } it { should contain_service('nova-api').with( 'name' => commit_message:
Add support for Fedora 20

Since "Update to Fedora 20" (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/67505/)
was merged to diskimage-builder we should add support for Fedora
releases that are more than 19

Change-Id: Ic90d7380418ca5c3216aa3508930e607725ff177

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-03 12:20:31.000000000', 'files': ['functionaltests/api/base.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/solum/commit/c8d7224f62d7a8da08514c37acfa83e2754252c6', 'message': 'Fix Tempest tests failing on gate-solum-devstack-dsvm

Due to a new commit on tempest, all our devstack tests were
failing. This was due to an inheritance we have to RestClient

commit_message:
Fix Tempest tests failing on gate-solum-devstack-dsvm

Due to a new commit on tempest, all our devstack tests were
failing. This was due to an inheritance we have to RestClient
from tempest. The signature of the constructor has changed.

This patch changes the signature of our inherited classes to
match the change from tempest

Fixes bug 1275697

Change-Id: I848d4b70d3b5129295d4aec5edbd4c03428ca0cc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/solum refs/changes/02/70702/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: def __init__(self, config, username, password, auth_url, tenant_name=None): super(SolumClient, self).__init__(config, username, password, auth_url, tenant_name) client_args = (CONF, username, password, auth_url, tenant_name)

commit_message:
Move command references from section to chapters

Rename sections to chapters for the command references.

Update cli-reference to remove single "command references" chapter and
add a chapter per command.

Adjust training-guides.

Change-Id: I64b30bca4915eed4f312bb3d2b5692c11b19fc81

commit_message:
Remove Command Reference appendix

Remove the appendix from End User and Admin User guides.
Add new manual to the list of all manuals in the support appendix.

Update references to point to new book.

Change-Id: I0cc12c45b5487a18c8de285f4ef939dcab4c4831

commit_message:
VMware: raise specific exception for file already exists

In certain cases the exception handling for backend errors
would be handled too broadly. This patch elevates the backend exception
to the application so that it can treat specific errors.

Related-Bug: #1266579
Related-Bug: #1266580

Change-Id: I9d154c430a0073a78224feb92804b46556eb535e
Co-authored-by: Matthew Booth <mbooth@redhat.com>

add tests for force delete snapshot:

- test_snapshot_force_delete_when_snapshot_is_creating
- test_snapshot_force_delete_when_snapshot_is_deleting
- test_snapshot_force_delete_when_snapshot_is_error
- test_snapshot_force_delete_when_snapshot_is_error_deleting

Change-Id: If03e21ee5b617476aa84f6512d2a6346194c9fcb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/13/66813/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _create_temp_snapshot(self): # Create a temp snapshot for force delete tests snp_name = data_utils.rand_name('Snapshot') resp, temp_snapshot = self.client.create_snapshot(self.volume['id'], display_name=snp_name) self.client.wait_for_volume_status(temp_snapshot['id'], 'available') return temp_snapshot def _create_reset_and_force_delete_temp_snapshot(self, status=None): # Create snapshot, reset snapshot status, and force delete temp snapshot temp_snapshot = self._create_temp_snapshot() if status: resp, body = self.admin_snapshots_client.\ reset_snapshot_status(temp_snapshot['id'], status) self.assertEqual(202, resp.status) resp_delete, volume_delete = self.admin_volume_client.\ force_delete_snapshot(temp_snapshot['id']) self.assertEqual(202, resp_delete.status) self.client.wait_for_resource_deletion(temp_snapshot['id']) @attr(type='gate') def test_snapshot_force_delete_when_snapshot_is_creating(self): # test force delete when status of snapshot is creating self._create_reset_and_force_delete_temp_snapshot('creating') @attr(type='gate') def test_snapshot_force_delete_when_snapshot_is_deleting(self): # test force delete when status of snapshot is deleting self._create_reset_and_force_delete_temp_snapshot('deleting') @attr(type='gate') def test_snapshot_force_delete_when_snapshot_is_error(self): # test force delete when status of snapshot is error self._create_reset_and_force_delete_temp_snapshot('error') @attr(type='gate') def test_snapshot_force_delete_when_snapshot_is_error_deleting(self): # test force delete when status of snapshot is error_deleting self._create_reset_and_force_delete_temp_snapshot('error_deleting')

Since these sections are not needed for the appendices anymore, we
can use chapters for the command reference. This patch changes
the tool to write chapters.

Change-Id: Ibbb2334120bc40b1c147432c9a089186c484a4fa
'}]
commit_message:
Generate chapters instead of sections for commands

Since these sections are not needed for the appendices anymore, we
can use chapters for the command reference. This patch changes
the tool to write chapters.

Change-Id: Ibbb2334120bc40b1c147432c9a089186c484a4fa

expected to run into location not found exception. However,
because the error message is rewritten in v2 image update,
so user will get below wrong message:
Failed to find image <image-id> to update

This fix will remove the rewritten message, given the NotFound
message has been set at: glance/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#L159

Closes-Bug: #1265448

Change-Id: I4e5fbbe40ce0fd13e828a40a424d4fcdc66a236b
"}]
commit_message:
Don't rewrite the NotFound error message

When user updates an image with a nonexisted location, it's
expected to run into location not found exception. However,
because the error message is rewritten in v2 image update,
so user will get below wrong message:
Failed to find image <image-id> to update

This fix will remove the rewritten message, given the NotFound
message has been set at: glance/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#L159

Closes-Bug: #1265448

Change-Id: I4e5fbbe40ce0fd13e828a40a424d4fcdc66a236b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/01/69201/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: except exception.NotFound as e: raise webob.exc.HTTPNotFound(explanation=unicode(e))
deleted_lines: except exception.NotFound: msg = (_("Failed to find image %(image_id)s to update") % {'image_id': image_id}) LOG.info(msg) raise webob.exc.HTTPNotFound(explanation=msg)

commit_message:
Don't match commented [DEFAULT]

Class ceilometer::agent::compute fails when there are [DEFAULT] sections
commented. This patch is fixing this issue. For more info check
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1060712

commit_message:
Adds a summary to the Projects and Users chapter

Change-Id: I8fc478f3eefa62b495c34cc90c9a93b448710245
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/operations-guide refs/changes/23/69023/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" version="5.0" xml:id="projects_users"> Managing Projects and Users An OpenStack cloud does not have much value without users. This chapter covers topics that relate to managing users, projects, and quotas. This chapter describes users and projects as described by version 2 of the OpenStack Identity API. Version 3 offers groups and domains as well which we discuss later in this chapter.
Projects or Tenants? In OpenStack user interfaces and documentation, a group of users is referred to as a project or tenant. These terms are interchangeable. The initial implementation of the OpenStack Compute Service (nova) had its own authentication system and used the term project. When authentication moved into the OpenStack Identity Service (keystone) project, it used the term tenant to refer to a group of users. Because of this legacy, some of the OpenStack tools refer to projects and some refer to tenants. This guide uses the term project, unless an example shows interaction with a tool that uses the term tenant.
Managing Projects Users must be associated with at least one project, though they may belong to many. Therefore, you should add at least one project before adding users.
Adding Projects To create a project through the dashboard: Log in as an administrative user. Select the "Projects" link in the left hand navigation bar. Click on the "Create Project" button at the top right. You are prompted for a project name and an optional, but recommended, description. Select the check box at the bottom of the form to enable this project. By default, this is enabled.
deleted_lines:
xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" version="5.0" xml:id="projects_users"> Managing Projects and Users An OpenStack cloud does not have much value without users. This chapter covers topics that relate to managing users, projects, and quotas.
Projects or Tenants? In OpenStack user interfaces and documentation, a group of users is referred to as a project or tenant. These terms are interchangeable. The initial implementation of the OpenStack Compute Service (nova) had its own authentication system and used the term project. When authentication moved into the OpenStack Identity Service (keystone) project, it used the term tenant to refer to a group of users. Because of this legacy, some of the OpenStack tools refer to projects and some refer to tenants. This guide uses the term project, unless an example shows interaction with a tool that uses the term tenant.
Managing Projects Users must be associated with at least one project, though they may belong to many. Therefore, you should add at least one project before adding users.
Adding Projects To create a project through the dashboard: Log in as an administrative user. Select the "Projects" link in the left hand navigation bar. Click on the "Create Project" button at the top right. You are prompted for a project name and an optional, but recommended, description. Select the check box at the bottom of the form to enable this project. By default, this is enabled.

commit_message:
driver: include the original exception if fails to load

When a driver tries to load one extension and fails to do so, the
current message is coming from _init_plugins() that states that no
extension were found. Otherwise, that might be wrong. The problem could
be that invoke_on_load=True was set and that the driver was unable to be
instanciated. In that case, it's much better to include this exception
string into the original exception, so it eases the debugging.

This fixes #32

Change-Id: I200705a43f571cf8c351615f24470f6bc2fadf29
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/stevedore refs/changes/62/62462/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: names=None, catch_exception=True): :param catch_exception: Whether to catch extension loading exception and log them, or re-raise them. if catch_exception: LOG.error('Could not load %r: %s', ep.name, err) LOG.exception(err) else: raise
deleted_lines: names=None): LOG.error('Could not load %r: %s', ep.name, err) LOG.exception(err)

commit_message:
Add timer for atomic actions

Execution time is now measured for atomic actions, so we have time
measuring for the whole benchmark and also detailed for each atomic
action.

Added the decorator atomic_action_timer and used it in nova, cinder
and keystone scenarios.

Partially implements: blueprint time-measuring-of-atomic-actions
(Part "I) Core" of time-measuring-of-atomic-actions)

Change-Id: I99571ef1221757784ce2b85889ad989fcae05bb2

commit_message:
VNC must be disabled to enable SPICE

The SPICE console is available only if the VNC console is disabled.
Provide this information in the config-reference.

Change-Id: I4b84bb4c9a29ee1702bc1643556cc0090c721791

subject: Fix idle time in timeout case
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-03 13:44:44.000000000', 'files': ['rally/benchmark/runner.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/rally/commit/a89df76c177d4fef59162aedb6920fab17939b74', 'message': 'Fix idle time in timeout case

After switch from classess to instance of scenario classes we
stopped storeing idle time in cls. So in case of timeout, code like:

Change-Id: I54b6f87a45560b0c98ce6eeb60d27decfa06ad5b
Closes-bug: #1275724

commit_message:
Fix idle time in timeout case

After switch from classess to instance of scenario classes we
stopped storeing idle time in cls. So in case of timeout, code like:
> cls.idle_time will produce error

Change-Id: I54b6f87a45560b0c98ce6eeb60d27decfa06ad5b
Closes-bug: #1275724
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/16/70716/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: result = {"time": timeout, "idle_time": 0, result = {"time": timeout, "idle_time": 0, result = {"time": timeout, "idle_time": 0,
deleted_lines: result = {"time": timeout, "idle_time": cls.idle_time, result = {"time": timeout, "idle_time": cls.idle_time, result = {"time": timeout, "idle_time": cls.idle_time,

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-03 13:00:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tooz/commit/2816b9fe3c3b5b6329f0a0b5fa6682c324893d48', 'message': 'Remove _wrap_call_kazoo

API. Besides, because of it all functions will always

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-02-03 13:02:27.000000000', 'files': ['tooz/drivers/zookeeper.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tooz/commit/069c3d308d744809473f083679f0785628d0d6e6', 'message': 'Remove _wrap_call_kazoo

commit_message:
Remove _wrap_call_kazoo

_wrap_call_kazoo is no longer needed in the async
API. Besides, because of it all functions will always
raise the ToozError exception instead of a more specialized
one because ZooKeeperError is catched first.

Change-Id: I2ce4addfd43b21a4ff0f8131f3a40eb91cdbce8c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tooz refs/changes/09/70709/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: except exceptions.ZookeeperError as e: raise coordination.ToozError(str(e)) async_result = self._coord.create_async(group_path) except exceptions.ZookeeperError as e: raise coordination.ToozError(str(e)) async_result = self._coord.create_async(member_path, value=capabilities, ephemeral=True) async_result = self._coord.delete_async(member_path) except exceptions.ZookeeperError as e: raise coordination.ToozError(str(e)) else: return members_ids async_result = self._coord.get_children_async(group_path) except exceptions.ZookeeperError as e: raise coordination.ToozError(str(e)) async_result = self._coord.set_async(member_path, capabilities) except exceptions.ZookeeperError as e: raise coordination.ToozError(str(e)) else: return capabilities async_result = self._coord.get_async(member_path) except exceptions.ZookeeperError as e: raise coordination.ToozError(str(e)) else: return group_ids async_result = self._coord.get_children_async(tooz_namespace)
deleted_lines: async_result = self._wrap_kazoo_call(self._coord.create_async, group_path) async_result = self._wrap_kazoo_call(self._coord.create_async, member_path, value=capabilities, ephemeral=True) async_result = self._wrap_kazoo_call(self._coord.delete_async, member_path) members_ids = None return members_ids async_result = self._wrap_kazoo_call(self._coord.get_children_async, group_path) async_result = self._wrap_kazoo_call(self._coord.set_async, member_path, capabilities) capabilities = "" return capabilities async_result = self._wrap_kazoo_call(self._coord.get_async, member_path) group_ids = [] return group_ids async_result = self._wrap_kazoo_call(self._coord.get_children_async, tooz_namespace) def _wrap_kazoo_call(self, func, *args, **kwargs): """Call and catch ZooKeeperError.""" try: return func(*args, **kwargs) except exceptions.ZookeeperError as e: raise coordination.ToozError(str(e))

commit_message:
Attempt to clarify devstack-gate graduation requirement

In today's TC meeting, we discussed and arrived at this clarification of
the devstack-gate requirement for graduation.

Change-Id: I6504b0c55b0fa372af9c4be46e115f4b11323c26

deleted_lines: ** Project must be part of the integrated gate

subject: Fix order of arguments in assertEqual
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-12-25 14:56:30.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient/commit/3b2ce82708bd1da9bd9fba42eefbfc99efae0d68', 'message': 'Fix order of arguments in assertEqual

Some tests used incorrect order assertEqual(observed, expected).

commit_message:
Fix order of arguments in assertEqual

Some tests used incorrect order assertEqual(observed, expected).

The correct order expected by testtools is
assertEqual(expected, observed).

Change-Id: I1184cb9f163ffb6416be32ddb1386c3bfd9b1006
Closes-Bug: #1259292

longer runs puppetmaster).

to openstack::controller_ha so that haproxy::balancermember always sets
the primary controller as the active server in failover configurations.

failover to active-active load balancing between controller nodes.

internal.

options to prevent it from issuing a warning that is not relevant for
Puppet versions 2.7 and newer.

Change-Id: I5fa03dbc3f7e3a7dfa57c226a5396f652c111997

Change-Id: Ia7a7ea53d26e0f2bf976a8b195a39dcada5a0756
'}]
commit_message:
Finish configuring a service before adding it to HAProxy

Starting an HAProxy instance for ceilometer-api (and possibly other
similar services) will fail on Ubuntu if the package for that service is
installed but not yet configured: the service is still running in its
default configuration binding to 0.0.0.0 instead of just the management
IP, preventing HAProxy from binding to the management VIP on the same
port.

To prevent a dependency loop (Ceilometer, like most other OpenStack
services, depends on MySQL), Galera dependencies have to be narrowed
down from the whole of HAProxy setup to just the registration of MySQL
service with it. HAProxy related parts of controller_ha and galera
classes are refactored to support reloading HAProxy for each service
independently, and to group together HAProxy options specific to
individual services.

To support granular addition of services into HAProxy, haproxy module
updated to puppetlabs-haproxy 1.0.1 (0d4c50e) and refactored to split
haproxy.cfg into multiple files under /etc/haproxy/conf.d using include
directive as implemented in the patch by Brane F. Granar:

http://marc.info/?l=haproxy&m=129235503410444

The define_backends option for haproxy class introduced in Fuel is
renamed to define_backups and ported to the new haproxy module.

Support for selecting exported haproxy::balancermember resources by tag
is dropped since it is no longer used (and not relevant since Fuel no
longer runs puppetmaster).

An ordered list of controllers is passed from osnailyfacter::cluster_ha
to openstack::controller_ha so that haproxy::balancermember always sets
the primary controller as the active server in failover configurations.

HAProxy configuration for RadosGW is changed from active-passive
failover to active-active load balancing between controller nodes.
Backend IP addresses for RadosGW servers are changed from storage to
internal.

Added "--no-class_inherits_from_params_class-check" to puppet-lint
options to prevent it from issuing a warning that is not relevant for
Puppet versions 2.7 and newer.

Change-Id: I5fa03dbc3f7e3a7dfa57c226a5396f652c111997
Closes-bug: #1264388

Change-Id: Ia7a7ea53d26e0f2bf976a8b195a39dcada5a0756

commit_message:
Install packages required to build clients

These were dropped when the package support was added, they are not
required for package builds but for now there is no way to select an
element wide install script based on install type. So we install in
all cases.

Also adding 3 new dependencies(python-virtualenv, libxml2-dev and
libxslt-dev) that were never listed but are required.

Closes-Bug: #1274846
Change-Id: I8eb04b6d1527de43b768e2b51a1c916202ea5ee9

commit_message:
Fixed OSTF tests for Murano 0.4.1 release.

Removed two extra test cases with deployment of Server Farms,
because Murano uses Neutron Load Balancer for Server Farms and we
have no support of Neutron LB in Mirantis OpenStack.

Also fixed issue with keypairs for linux-based services (it is changed
in Murano and OSTF tests should meet new Murano changes)

Implements blueprint: do-not-use-key-pair-for-murano-ostf-tests

Change-Id: I1066f01e2ff1cc147b217c1bbe1c1d112af06b0f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-ostf refs/changes/54/69554/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: def find_keypair(self, keyname): """ Returns True if keypair exists. """ return keyname in [k.id for k in self.compute_client.keypairs.list()]
